Title: The most underrated city in Italy: Milan. Some reasons why you should explore it.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
I’m Italian, from Naples, south of Italy, but I fell in love with Milan and the northern part of the country. For those who know our history, my statement sounds strange, because usually people from the south don’t like some places in the north and vice versa. Italy became united in 1861, but still nowadays we are very different when it comes to food, history and language (we have many dialects — used mostly in the south). Naples was the capital of the southern part of Italy and the unification has been perceived as a conquest. The south has always been seen like the underdeveloped part of the country even if it actually used to be rich, also from a cultural point of view. For so many years the people from the north had been calling us “terroni” (a pejorative word to define the people who worked in the fields). It still happens sometimes, unfortunately. Imagine that in the past it was almost impossible for a person from the south to find a house to rent in the north, because they used to say: “we don’t rent houses to people from the south” — especially people from Naples. I could write a book about why this happened and there are many political reasons of course. Still nowadays the money from the south is used in the north so the result is that the north is more efficient when it comes to transportation, jobs and quality of life, while the south struggles with the very little things. My family emigrated to the north for a while when I was not even born and my mother still can’t believe I love living in the north. She had a bad experience in the 60s when she moved close to Milan. She told me that when she finally found a house, after facing many prejudices just because she was from Naples, she was still looked with suspicion by the landlord for a lot of time before being finally accepted as a “good person”.
Why am I telling you this? Well, because probably now you can understand how strange it sounds the fact that as a Neapolitan I love Milan like I’ve never loved a place before.
Fortunately nowadays the situation has changed and many Milanese people love Naples and go there for tourism. When I moved there a year ago, it took me months to be accepted by some people but now I can say I have many friends in Milan and in spite of the prejudices that this place can have when it comes to people from my city, I can’t help but loving the Milanese culture.
Many people think that Milan has nothing more but the Duomo and that it’s not an historic place due to the modern architecture of the skyscrapers. Well, as a tour guide that from Naples and Pompeii decided to move to this beautiful city, let me tell you that this is a huge misconception. Milan is a very ancient city that was founded by the Celts in the VI century b. C. and it also became the capital of the western part of the Roman Empire! Probably you wouldn’t expect to find Roman ruins, but you can actually find them in different parts of the city. One of my favorite spots is The Imperial Roman palace, or at least what remains of it, and it’s still there on via Brisa!
Ruins of the imperial palace
If you don’t like the Roman time, and maybe you prefer frescoes and churches, Milan has also a hidden gem called “The Sistine Chapel of Milan”! I’m talking about San Maurizio al Monastero Maggiore with its beautiful frescoes.
San Maurizio al Monastero Maggiore
This place looks very anonymous from the outside, but inside it’s a work of art and it’s totally free! You don’t need a ticket to admire this beauty.
Unfortunately Milan is not famous for these little hidden gems due to the fashion industry. Don’t forget that this is the Fashion capital of Italy and every February/March and September/October you can enjoy the Fashion Week, admiring beautiful models through the streets of the center and taking part to Fashion exhibitions.
So, Milan has a lot to offer when it comes to history, fashion but also food! I define Milan as the Italian New York, not only for the skyscrapers, but because it’s a melting pot. Here you will find not only the typical Milanese food, but also food from other regions! Well, after the unification that I mentioned before, step by step, Milan has also become the financial capital of Italy and many people, in spite of the prejudices, decided to move there to find a good job and have a better life. That’s why nowadays it’s possible to find food from Tuscany, Sicily, Puglia… and even from my beautiful city, Naples!
If you want to go for the traditional Milanese food , try rice with saffron with ossobuco! You can’t leave Milan without trying it first!
Ok, I can hear you from my couch asking for it. You can try it at Locanda del Menarost, which is one of my favorite places for Milanese food.
Picture taken from google
If you prefer to have food that can be more expensive but in an historical environment, you can choose from the many restaurants in the stunning Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, the first shopping gallery in Italy!
That’s me in the beautiful Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II (when I was just a tourist)
I hope I gave you enough reasons to hop on a flight and come to explore this beautiful but underrated city in Italy. Milan is so much more than the Fashion Week and the modern city made of skyscrapers!
If you want to know more about it, keep reading the next articles or book me for a tour! I’ll be happy to show you this city through my eyes.

Tour guide and tour leader in Naples & Milan . I love writing about travel, coffee and Italy. Follow me on IG to be updated about my tours and travel tips!

Life in Milan, Italy, is characterized by a blend of rich history, modern culture, and a fast-paced urban lifestyle. As Italy’s financial and fashion capital, Milan offers a vibrant city life with a strong economy, diverse culture, and a cosmopolitan atmosphere.
### Culture and LifestyleMilan is known for its cultural landmarks, including the iconic Duomo di Milano, the opera house La Scala, and numerous art galleries and museums, such as the Pinacoteca di Brera. The city also plays a significant role in the global fashion industry, hosting Milan Fashion Week and being home to luxury brands like Prada and Versace.
### Work and BusinessBeing Italy’s economic hub, Milan is a great place for business professionals, with many multinational companies and financial institutions headquartered here. The city offers opportunities in fashion, finance, design, technology, and manufacturing.
### TransportationMilan has an efficient public transportation system, including buses, trams, and a well-connected metro. Its central location makes it easy to travel within Italy and throughout Europe, with two major airports (Malpensa and Linate) and a high-speed rail network.

Title: Visiting Milan, Italy. A brief history and highlights of the city.
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
“The world is a book and those who do not travel read only one page.” — St. Augustine
After an exhausting business trip that took me from Amsterdam to Cologne to Hamburg to Vienna, I decided to visit the beautiful city of Milan (Milano). Having previously been to Rome, where every corner of the city amused me like a child, I didn’t hesitate to choose Milan, the fashion capital as my next destination.
My final destination in Austria was Wörgl, a small city in the center of the country. I enjoyed the train journey from Vienna to Wörgl and decided to take the train to Milan. Surprisingly, the train was crowded and not as high quality as the trains I had used in Germany or Austria. Nevertheless, I arrived in Milan in the evening and, as always, booked an Airbnb house. When booking accommodation, I always make sure to stay with locals rather than just renting an apartment for myself. I used public transport to get to the nearest metro station and walked my way into the house. My host gave me some suggestions for the best Italian food places in the area, and I had the most delicious risotto for dinner from a nearby restaurant.
Milan — A Brief History.
As a history enthusiast, I must write something about Milan’s medieval and modern history. The initial settlement of Milan is considered to be around 400 BC and then conquered by the Romans. Even though there were wars and the Great Plague of Milan (which killed 60000 people), I would write about the 17th century when Napoleon invaded Italy and made Milan it's capital. Then in the 18th century, Austria took over the city. The Austrians were ousted in 1858 with a rebellion and the country was united again. Milan was considerably damaged by world war II and it was also occupied by German forces for 2 years at the end of the war. It's impressive that most of the city is reconstructed after WWII.
The Milan Cathedral (Milan Duomo)
Milan Duomo, or Milan Cathedral (of Santa Maria), is an awe-inspiring Gothic cathedral that is among the largest in the world. It's intricate design and ornate decoration make it a must-see attraction and probably the most iconic structure in the whole of Milan. Truly magnificent.
The construction of the cathedral started in 1386 and passed through different significant stages in the 14th, 15th and 17th centuary. The construction even went on in the 18th and 19th centuries and that explains the complexity of the structure. The Cathedral is 102 meters tall with 135 spires.
I went to the cathedral rooftop by the stairs (stone laid) where we get a nice view of the city and the spires surrounding the roof. It was quite sunny but it was all worth the time spent there on top.
The vibe around the Duomo is different in the evenings. Street artists performing and visitors sinking into the calm night — I felt relaxed sitting on the stairs in front of the cathedral in admiration enjoying my own company and the sight.
Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II
When you visit Milan Cathedral, you cannot miss the close by grand shopping arcade — Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II. Constructed between 1865 and 1877, it connects Milan Duomo and La Scala. The Galleria is renowned for its beautiful architecture, featuring a stunning glass and iron roof, intricate mosaics, and neoclassical details. The Galleria is home to a variety of super luxury stores, boutiques, restaurants, and cafes.
One of the most popular traditions associated with the Galleria is the “ritual of the bull.” Visitors to the Galleria often spin on their heels three times on the mosaic of the bull located on the floor of the arcade. According to tradition, this brings good luck and ensures a return trip to Milan.
While I was enjoying the beauty of the arcade in the crowd, there was a group singing “Hare Krishna Hare Rama” from the Hari Krishna temple of Milan. It was really a happy moment and great to get the Indian spiritual touch in Milan.
Santa Maria Delle Grazie
Santa Maria Delle Grazie is a church best known for being home to the famous mural painting, “The Last Supper,” by the Italian Renaissance artist Leonardo da Vinci. The church and convent itself have beautiful architecture and artwork. It needs a prior booking to see the Last Supper painting because of its fragile condition. Unfortunately, I was not aware of the long waiting times. I was informed the next available visiting slot is after a month :). Well — now I have an unfinished business in Milan and a good reason to go back!
The Monumental Cemetery
The cemetery was built in the 18th century in an attempt to consolidate different small cemeteries around the city. It is one of the 2 major cemeteries in the city. The cemetery welcomes us with a big hall-like entrance with the tombs of renowned citizens of the city. It is made of marble and stones. It also houses the tomb of the poet and novelist Alessandro Manzoni at the center of the hall. When we walk past the hall into the open cemetery, we can sight the tombs designed by artists and most of them have beautiful sculptures on them. The cemetery is by far the most artistic cemetery I have ever seen. Walking through the cemetery and reading the names and the years they lived, it almost feels like meeting people from the 18th century to the 20th century with just one difference — they are dead and we aren’t.
Teatro alla Scala, or La Scala
This ladies and gentlemen — blew my mind. Marvelous would be an understatement. La Scala — meaning the Stairs is a globally known opera house where renowned artists for centuries perform. Its arranged in a semi-circular shape with four stories with boxes. The opera house was opened in the 17th century. The current form of what we see of the theatre is after the renovation done in 1907 with 1987 seats including boxes. The theatre was severely damaged in WWII and was rebuilt again in 1946. The theatre has red upholstery finish overall with classic chandeliers to light it up. La Scala whispers in our ears to leave mediocrity and get to excellence — that is the level of performances and artists who perform there.
The Navigli District
The article wouldn’t be complete without a mention about the best area to have some food and drinks and that is Navigli area. The area has canals and restaurants and bars on both sides of it. The place is lively and you can see visitors and locals all flocking to this area over the evenings.
I had delicious pasta from one of the restaurants with a nice beer to chill.
Sforzesco Castle
The Castello Sforzesco is a medieval fortification in Milan. It was built in the 15th century by Francesco Sforza, the Duke of Milan. This was one attraction that didn’t wow me but is still a piece of work with its huge size.
To End
There is more to Milan than the historic attractions. The city has some really modern buildings and some attractive flats with vertical gardens in it. Not to forget it is the fashion capital and the presense of many renowned brands. I was also able to try the famous italian Gelatos, the 1 Euro coffee shots, the famous Italian pizzas and more. If you want to visit Italy — Milan is definitely worth a visit.

Title: TWO DAYS IN MILAN — THE CITY WHERE THE PAST SHAPES THE FUTURE
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
About a month ago, a dear friend of mine from Chile, a great art and culture enthusiast, came to visit me in Milan. I took the opportunity to show him, in just two days, both the most iconic and the lesser-known places in my city. I decided to share our itinerary with you to offer a unique perspective on Milan, exploring those curiosities only a local would know.
We woke up around nine and immediately left the house to enjoy a typical Italian breakfast. We sat at one of the tables outside my favorite café, Dolci Memela in the De Angeli area, and had a cappuccino with an “Ischitana” (a croissant with a double layer of pastry and a generous filling) with pistachio. We then headed to the nearest metro station and took it to reach the city center.
Our first stop was, of course, the Milan Cathedral, or Duomo, one of the city’s most emblematic landmarks. It’s the third-largest church in Europe, in Gothic style, adorned with marble spires and pinnacles reaching up into the blue sky: it is a majestic sight, and as a Milanese, I’m very proud of it.
We entered the cathedral and found ourselves in the middle of a towering nave, which we walked through, admiring sculptures and paintings. Then we climbed the stairs to the roof and stopped to take in the splendid view of the city.
From the terraces, you can also clearly see another cherished Milan symbol: the Madonnina, a statue over four meters tall depicting the Virgin Mary, covered in gold and situated on the highest spire of the cathedral. Looking at it, we were almost blinded by the sun’s fierce reflections.
We then proceeded to the next stop, just a five-minute walk away: the Church of San Satiro. As soon as we stepped inside, we were struck by Bramante’s illusory fresco from the 15th century. Through a masterful use of perspective, Bramante skillfully deceives the viewer’s eye: the apse appears to be several meters deep, but in reality, it extends only a few centimeters.
After leaving the church, we headed to Piazza Mercanti, where there’s a medieval loggia with a unique acoustic feature. I invited my friend to stand in one corner by a pillar and place his ear against it. I then positioned myself at the opposite end, near another pillar, and spoke facing the column. Despite the several-meter distance, he could hear me perfectly! This effect is produced by the peculiar architectural structure of the vault, designed so that merchants could communicate with each other without being overheard by customers.
We also visited the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, an authentic 19th-century architectural gem exuding class and elegance. We strolled beneath its majestic glass dome, and I invited him to take part in an old tradition: at the center of the gallery, there’s a mosaic depicting a bull, and it’s said that turning three times on one’s heel over the bull’s genitals brings good luck.
We passed by the Teatro alla Scala, one of the world’s most famous opera houses, whose entrance was unfortunately under renovation, and then arrived at the Casa degli Omenoni. This 16th-century building is known for its imposing facade dominated by six massive statues of burly men, representing the barbarian peoples defeated by imperial Rome. Originally the residence of the Milanese patron Leone Leoni, today the Casa degli Omenoni hosts the Clubino, an exclusive gentlemen’s club, so access is restricted to the public.
We then strolled to Via Montenapoleone, the main artery of the Quadrilatero della moda, an iconic crossroad lined with boutiques from Europe’s most exclusive fashion brands. Milan is indeed considered one of the four fashion capitals, alongside Paris, London, and New York, and is particularly famous for its Fashion Week.
We then moved on to the nearby Brera district, known for its bohemian atmosphere, where we stopped to eat at the Taverna del Borgo Antico, offering a wide selection of typical Milanesi dishes.
After lunch, we headed towards Castello Sforzesco, an impressive medieval fortress built by Milan’s ancient rulers, which now houses various museums and temporary exhibitions. We stopped to admire the Pietà Rondanini, an evocative sculpture by Michelangelo Buonarroti, depicting the Madonna with the dead body of Jesus in her arms. It’s his last work, clearly unfinished, as shown by the rough, sketchy contours, far from the meticulous realism of his other masterpieces. Yet, perhaps it’s precisely the imperfection that touches the soul, effectively highlighting, through Mary’s deformed, incomplete face, the grief of a mother struggling to support her son’s lifeless body.
Then, we walked towards the Arco della Pace, erected by Napoleon to celebrate his conquests in Italy and symbolically facing its Parisian counterpart, before heading back through Parco Sempione, a large green space that allowed us to briefly escape the urban environment.
When we finally arrived at the next stop, the Church of San Maurizio, we found it closed. It was a shame, as it’s well renowned for its splendid paintings and has been boldly nicknamed the “Sistine Chapel of Milan”.
We ended our tour with Il Dito (The Finger), an imposing sculpture depicting a raised middle finger facing the Milan Stock Exchange. Built after the 2008 crisis, it’s a simple yet ingenious critique of the financial world.
For dinner, we enjoyed an authentic Neapolitan pizza at Trattoria Caprese with a couple of friends. Later on, we rode the metro all together to the Darsena area, one of the hotspots of Milan’s nightlife. We had an Ichnusa beer at one of the many crowded bars along the Naviglio Grande, a large artificial canal built in the heart of the city, and then took a final stroll before heading home.
But Milan isn’t just about art and history, so the next day I took my friend to see the city’s more modern side. After another breakfast with typical pastries, we walked to City Life, characterized by three towering skyscrapers. One of these, the Libeskind Tower, commonly known as Il Curvo (the Curved One), has a unique feature: its folded shape is intentionally reminiscent of the Pietà Rondanini. It’s the perfect representation of Milan’s spirit: blending progress with tradition, the future with the past.
Side by side with Il Curvo there is another skyscraper, the Isozaky Tower, better known as Il Dritto (the Straight One), the tallest building in Milan and in Italy.
Another curious fact here: tradition dictates that the Madonnina should be placed at the highest point of the city, so, to honor this custom, a miniature replica of the statue sits atop the Isozaky Tower. This is another example of Milan’s profound desire to modernize while remaining faithful to its identity.
From City Life, we took the metro to the Porta Nuova district, a large area that has been transformed in recent decades, becoming the face of Milan’s modern side. Here there are some of the most innovative buildings in Milan: the Unicredit Tower and in particular the Bosco Verticale (Vertical Forest), which blends in a truly unique and bold way nature and human architecture.
We concluded our tour at San Siro: perhaps not the most modern or visually appealing stadium, but without any doubt a piece of soccer history, revered by fans of the sport. It has hosted some of the most successful teams of all time, Milan and Inter, the Devil and the Snake, and an impressive number of great champions, from Van Basten to Ibrahimović, Kaká, Eto’o, Seedorf, Gullit, and many others.
In short, Milan’s essence lies in its culture, marked by vibrant dynamism and an unstoppable drive toward progress, yet always respectful of its history, values, and traditions.
I’ll end with an old Milanese saying that rings true year after year, decade after decade:
Milan l’è on gran Milan
Milan is truly a great Milan

Writer, medical student, interested in Health, Travelling, Society, Technology, Politics, History and Economics.

Title: What Life in Milan Taught Me About Food, Fashion, and Community
Content:

Sign up
Sign in

For all the readers and writers in between cultures

Member-only story

30

Back in my teenage years, visiting Europe felt like a world away. My family comes from a very small city in Minas Gerais, Brazil, and at the time, traveling to places like Italy and France wasn’t even on the radar. Born in the U.S. but raised between Brazil and a small town in Florida, I still thought of Europe as an unattainable dream.
I adored movies set in France, London, and Italy. They spoke to my girly, high-fashion personality. The elegant charm of the scenery, the way people dressed, the amazing food, the art, and the historical significance — it all captivated me. Even New York City, technically much closer, felt out of reach.
At 20 years old, an unexpected opportunity came my way. A friend who had relocated from Florida to study at Parsons in NYC offered me a room in his Wall Street apartment for $1,000 a month. I didn’t have any savings — just a dream and a deep belief that there had to be more to life than what I was living. To make it happen, my dad sold my car for $2,000, which covered the first month’s rent. With the remaining $1,000, I took a leap of faith — and never looked back.

Title: Conquering Milan: A Student’s Guide to Budget Travel, Connectivity & Groceries
Content:

Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
Ciao a tutti! Dreaming of a semester abroad in the fashion capital Milan? Buckle up because this guide will have you navigating the city like a pro in no time.
Hitting the Ground Running: Airport Blues or Budget Bliss?
Just landed after a long flight? While a taxi might sound tempting but you’ll have to pre-book the same to avoid last-minute price hikes orelse listen to your wallet. The €10 airport bus is your budget hero, whisking you to the city center. Download the ATM Milano app beforehand and grab a €3, 90-minute travel card to avoid any ticketing troubles (fines are no fun!).
SIM Card Showdown: Tourist Traps vs. Student Savior
Hold off on those overpriced airport SIM cards! They’re designed for quick visits, not semester stays. Unless you’re rolling with a group and okay with occasional international call charges, wait until you settle in. Your accommodation likely has wifi, giving you time to research the best deals.
Conquering Connectivity: Public Transport & Phone Service
Milan’s public transport system is your best friend. Use the ATM Milano app to grab another €3, 90-minute pass and explore! For phone service, I recommend “Iliad.” Just grab your passport, head to a store near the Duomo (Milan’s stunning cathedral), and get your SIM card sorted. Activation takes 30 minutes, so why not browse Primark or Zara while you wait?
Becoming a Public Transport Pro: Monthly Pass Magic
Tired of fiddling with single tickets? Head to the ATM Milano website and grab a monthly pass. The “MONTHLY UNDER27 URBAN” pass covers 3 zones, but be sure to check which zones you’ll frequent most. Every penny saved is a delicious gelato earned! Important tip: While you can purchase the monthly pass online, it’s not a mobile pass. After booking, head to the Duomo metro station (or any ATM Point) to pick up your physical card. This card will be loaded with your monthly pass and will be scanned for entry on the public transport network.
www.thenestmilan.com
Supermarket Savvy: Your Guide to Student Eats
Now, let’s fuel those adventures! Milan boasts a variety of supermarkets, each with its own strengths:
Beyond the Basics: Your Milan Adventure Awaits!
This guide equips you with the essentials, but Milan has so much more to offer. From exploring historical landmarks to indulging in the city’s vibrant nightlife, the adventure awaits! Leave a comment below with what interests you most, and I’ll be happy to share more tips for an unforgettable semester in Milan.

Title: How to fall in love with the underrated city of Milan
Content:
Sign up

Sign up
Sign in
Member-only story
--
3

I really love Milan. And sometimes it feels like I’m the only one!
Both working in the travel industry and having many Italian friends, I hear a lot of feedback on this iconic city and hearing the way it’s described makes it clear to me that these people haven’t really given Milan a chance.
‘It’s just a big business city’. Say the Italians.
’It can be done in a day, just fly in and fly out’. Say the travel agents.
‘It doesn’t compare to Rome or Venice.‘ Say the tourists.
But what if we turn those statements around?
‘It’s just a big business city’.
Yes, it’s a big city. A big city that offers a mixture of neighbourhoods and vibes. A big city that’s full of twists and turns. A big city full of fun things to see and do.
’It can be done in a day, just fly in and fly out’.
But if you fly in and out, you’ll miss all of it’s greatness! You’ll miss Milan as it comes alive at night. You’ll leave before you even get a feel for the city and you’ll squeeze in just a fraction of the fun.
‘It doesn’t compare to Rome or Venice.‘

“Skip Milan,” they said. “It’s just a layover city,” they warned.
I almost believed them. Almost.
Standing in Milan’s Central Station three months ago, watching golden sunlight stream through the most breathtaking architecture I’d ever witnessed, I realized how wrong everyone was.
This wasn’t just another Italian city. This was a revelation waiting to happen.
Most travelers treat Milan like that friend you only call when you need something. A quick business stop. A fashion week appearance. Maybe a rushed connection between Rome and Switzerland.
But here’s what I discovered during my month-long stay: Milan isn’t the appetizer to your Italian adventure.
It’s the main course you never knew you were craving.
The moment you step into Milano Centrale, stop. Just stop.

Title: Is Milan Underrated? The Answer Is Yes, And Here’s Why
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

We are a group of ordinary yet extraordinary travel lovers sharing our experiences of exploring the world with the world.

Member-only story
--
7
Share
A traditional tram in Milan, most of them are over 100 years old!
I had planned a different topic for today, but the day’s events proved enlightening for another, and I wanted to seize the moment. “Carpe diem” they say, after all.
To run some bureaucratic errands, I traveled to Milan, the second largest city in Italy after Rome, but undoubtedly the economic capital and beating heart of the Italian economy. Having grown up in a small town in the vicinity of Como (yes, the Lake one), Milan has always been the reference point for a number of reasons, and throughout my entire childhood it has always represented what “a major city should be.” Then again, from my small town, I could reach it in only 40 minutes by train.
Having lived in cities like Santiago de Chile, Hanoi, and Melbourne; and having visited Buenos Aires, Bangkok, and London, I find it now funny how I had no idea what an actual megacity was. Milan is undoubtedly a large city by the standards of Italy, a country consisting of many medium-sized cities, but lacking a megacity that exceeds 10 million inhabitants like almost all the ones I have listed.

Content:

Last year I went on a month-long journey through the North of Italy. In this article, I want to share some of the highlights that I made on the tour. Additionally, I thought I’d complement my own thoughts with impressions of German writer and poet Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, who visited Italy from 1786 to 1788.
My journey began in Milan, which is the second largest city in Italy after Rome. My first impression of the city was a bit disappointing as I perceived it as quite dirty and ran down. Maybe this was due to the fact that my hostel was located next to the main station, which is not the best area in town.
The hostel itself, however, was very nice. I would do a lot of exploring around the center of the city. Two of the main sites are the Milan Cathedral and the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II. The former was built in 1386, and I highly recommend taking a tour through the Cathedral, including the rooftop.
The Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is Italy’s oldest active shopping gallery. It stands out due to its high ceilings, the glass dome in the center, and its luxurious shops and restaurants within the gallery. I found the architecture very fascinating, although it is obviously overrun by tourists.
After a short stay in Bergamo, I headed out to Verona, the city of Romeo and Juliett. Verona has a nice Mediterranean vibe and is home to the Verona Arena, one of the best-preserved Roman amphitheaters.
It was built in 30 AD and is still in use today. Goethe wrote about the amphitheater:
“The simplicity of the oval is palpable to every eye in the most pleasant way, and every head serves as a measure of how enormous the whole is. Now, when you see it empty, you have no measure; you do not know whether it is big or small.”
Although the amphitheater is one of the city’s main attractions, what stood out to me was the general architecture you can find throughout the city. There is a beautiful hill, home to the Castel San Pietro, from which you are able to overlook the city.
Lake Garda, which is easily reachable from Verona, was my next stop. What stood out to me was the panoramic view, with the majestical mountains of the Alps in the background. Goethe was also enraptured by this view:
“How much do I wish that my friends were with me for a moment to enjoy the prospect, which now lies before my eyes. I might have been in Verona this evening, but a magnificent natural phenomenon was in my vicinity — Lake Garda, a splendid spectacle, which I did not want to miss, and now I am nobly rewarded for taking this circuitous route.”
I stayed in a small town called Desenzano del Garda, which is a great hub for exploring the surrounding areas. Even in late October, you are able to enjoy some hours at the lake’s beaches.
My next stop on the list was Venice — a town I have seen so many times in various movies but never in person. So as soon as I left the train station and saw the canal in the beautiful sunshine, I had a big smile on my face. I stayed in a hostel called the Generator, which is located on one of the smaller side islands but offers a great view of the city.
Now, Venice really is a place of its own. You do not need to visit museums or galleries because the city itself is a piece of art. It gained wealth and power between the 9th and 12th centuries and had another very influential phase during the Renaissance. The boats, the houses, the canals. Everything in Venice feels magical, and you could easily believe that the city is a well-constructed theme park.
Note, however, that many tourists are moving through the narrow alleys of which Goethe wrote:
“After dinner, I hurried to first get an impression of the whole, and threw myself (…) into the labyrinth of the city, which, although intersected by canals and small channels, is connected again by bridges and small bridges. One cannot imagine the narrowness and crowdedness of the whole without having seen it.”
After I left Venice and spent one night in Bologna, I headed further south to Florence. Now, if you’re a fan of DaVinci, Michelangelo, or art in general, this city is a must-see! Although I was already a bit tired of the hustling and bustling of all the cities I’d seen, I managed to visit the Uffizi, which hosts one of the most important collections of the Renaissance era.
What I enjoyed even more in Florence was the community kitchen of my hostel — the Yellow Square. Every night a committed group of travelers would gather in the kitchen and share meals and stories of their day. Furthermore, the hostel has a nice rooftop terrace from where you can overlook the city.
Finally, it was time for me to head out into nature. I went to a place called LaVerna — an old, mystical monastery that is located on the top of a mountain. From there, I would start on a week-long pilgrimage along the way of St. Francis, which ultimately led me to the town of his birth, Assisi.
Thank you for reading this article. If you enjoy my writing, please follow my profile on medium. See you soon!

Associazione Calcio Milan, commonly referred to as AC Milan (Italian pronunciation: [a tˌtʃi mˈmiːlan]) or simply Milan, is an Italian professional football club based in Milan, Lombardy. Founded in 1899, the club competes in the Serie A, the top tier of Italian football. In its early history, Milan played its home games in different grounds around the city before moving to its current stadium, the San Siro, in 1926. The stadium, which was built by Milan’s second chairman, Piero Pirelli and has been shared with Inter Milan since 1947, is the largest in Italian football, with a total capacity of 75,817. The club has a long-standing rivalry with Inter, with whom they contest the Derby della Madonnina, one of the most followed derbies in football.
Milan has spent its entire history in Serie A with the exception of the 1980 — 81 and 1982 — 83 seasons. Silvio Berlusconi’s 31-year tenure as Milan president was a standout period in the club’s history, as they established themselves as one of Europe’s most dominant and successful clubs. Milan won 29 trophies during his tenure, securing multiple Serie A and UEFA Champions League titles. During the 1991 — 92 season, the club notably achieved the feat of being the first team to win the Serie A title without losing a single game. Milan is home to multiple Ballon d’Or winners, and three of the club’s players, Marco van Basten, Ruud Gullit, and Frank Rijkaard, were ranked in the top three on the podium for the 1988 Ballon d’Or, an unprecedented achievement in the history of the prize.

Milan is the second-most populous city in Italy and the capital of Lombardy. The population of the city is around 1.3 million while its urban area comprises an estimated 5 million people. Milan has the third largest economy among EU cities and the largest among European non-capital cities. Milan is the main industrial, commercial, and financial centre of Italy and a leading global city.
If you are in Milan, then you can feel, that there are more than 1.3 million people around you and everybody is a “big city” person. The streets were full of people, even on Sunday and everybody is shopping. Milan is one of the capitals of fashion, and you can touch it in the air.
We travelled in early April, and the weather was perfect for taking huge walks around the city and look into the life of Milan. People are fine in English, but in some places and situations, it is nice to have an Italian dictionary with you. Let me invite you to a one-day walk in the great Milan.
We are starting our day in the Central Railway Station of Milan. The building is huge considered to be one of the most beautiful European train stations. It was originally built in 1864 and is centrally located, not far away from many of Milan’s famous sites. Besides, the station is a great destination for high-end designer shopping.
After that, we take a short walk to Porta Nuova, Milan’s new district. The Porta Nuova Project has been under construction since the late 2000s. It is like a little New York in Milan with high rise buildings, cultural centres, and a large city park. You can take gorgeous pictures here.
The next stop is Arco della Pace and Porta Sempione (“Simplon Gate”), where we enter the historic city centre, but before we continue, take a small break here and look around you, the square with the gate and with the little yellow trams rattling. Isn’t it a beautiful place where you could take your breakfast every morning? — Yes I could, but we have to continue and see Arena Civica, which is one of the city’s leading examples of neoclassical architecture, today it is mainly the home of football and rugby union games, concerts and cultural events.
Before you feel hungry, take a small walk to the Sforzesco Castle, which was built in the 15th century by Francesco Sforza, Duke of Milan and today houses several of the city’s museums. The castle has a gorgeous garden with many flowers.
Ok, ok we have to take some break and eat some Italian. Milan has several excellent restaurants and we have tried many of them without disappointment. Taverna del Borgo Antico is a good place to take some good wine with a dish of “Pasta a la Carbonara”.
Our next stop is Teatro alla Scala, which is one of the leading opera and ballet theatres in the world. The theater was opened in 1778, and it is not a big deal from the outside, but if you have time and interest (what we didn’t), the interior is gorgeous.
We take a short walk to Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, one of the most beautiful places I ever been and the Galleria is one of the oldest shopping malls on our planet. It is an excellent spot for taking good pictures.
After we crossed the Galleria, we are coming to Piazza del Duomo, and then you can see the big deal in Milan. Yes, I mean the huge church in the middle of the square. The Cathedral together with the Galleria and the whole square with thousands of people are incredible. The Duomo di Milano is the fifth largest church of the word. It took thousands of workers, a new canal system and over six century to complete the constructions. You have to go inside the building and do not miss a walk on the roof because the view is fantastic.
Our tour ends in Naviglio Grande. If you have more than one day, then I can recommend The Museo Nazionale della Scienza e della Tecnologia Leonardo da Vinci, which has a great collection of Leonardo da Vinci’s work.
Do you want to have a great cocktail? Good Luck Café is a top notch bar with a great selection of premium spirits and kind staff.
Do you want to eat a Cannoli? Of course, you want. Ammu has the best Cannoli in the city, and even Italian queue themselves on Sunday to get one.
Pro Tips If you want to get rid of the lines, then buy your tickets on the internet before you take to Milan. Especially to the Cathedral and if you want to see The Last Supply. If you like shopping but hate the huge crowd, then definitely avoid the fashion street on a Sunday afternoon. Being in the center of Lombardy, you can easily plan one-day trips to the most famous tourist destinations of Northen-Italy. Have a coffee next to the Lake Como, stand under the balcony of Juliet in Verona or explore the great Florence.
Milan is an excellent destination to stay, where culture, fashion, shopping, eating, and drinking comes together and makes a perfect combination and a great atmosphere. The city has a great public transport system, with several metro lines, trams and you can even rent a bike if you are not that walking type of person.
Originally published at traveloth.com on November 30, 2016.

“My ‘80s Milan spoke American.”
(Silvia S. Castello, My American Summer, a memoir)
A conversation with Grok
Milan in the ’80s was indeed a magnetic hub, pulling in American flair while radiating its own bold identity — a transatlantic dance of style and ambition. Your memoir’s quote, “My ‘80s Milan spoke American,” captures that fusion perfectly. The 1983 MasterCard ad with Christie Brinkley, all glamour and effortless cool, mirrors the era’s vibe: aspirational, polished, yet accessible. It’s easy to see why meeting Richard, an American model, in that Milan felt like stepping into a living runway.
Milan was no mere backdrop; it was a cultural force. By the ’80s, it had cemented its status as a fashion capital, with designers like Armani, Versace, and Missoni defining global trends. And Enrico Coveri, “the king of colors”. Andy Warhol, a pop art icon, uniquely designed Coveri’s brand label, a rare collaboration that underscores Coveri’s influence across fashion and art during the 1980s. This was a significant moment, as Warhol rarely lent his artistic talents to branding in such a direct way. His collaboration with Coveri, wasn’t just a personal connection but a symbolic merging of art and fashion, America and Italy, during a decade defined by such exchanges. As a designer passionate about art, Coveri naturally gravitated toward contemporary artists like Warhol, Keith Haring, and Jean-Michel Basquiat, whose Pop Art influences are evident in his work. Warhol’s involvement with Coveri elevated the designer’s brand on a global stage, blending American Pop Art with Italian fashion. This mirrors the broader trend of the decade, where Milan’s runways became a global phenomenon, influencing American designers and consumers. The city’s runways weren’t just shows — they were spectacles, blending Italian craftsmanship with a newfound commercial swagger that resonated with America’s love for bold branding. For Americans, Milan was the ultimate destination, a place where sophistication met excess. Think Wall Street’s power suits meeting Quadrilatero d’Oro’s sleek boutiques.
The America-Milan pairing thrived on mutual fascination. America brought its pop culture muscle — MTV and movies like Flashdance — while Milan offered a curated rebellion, where every stitch was a statement. Clubs like Plastic and Amnesie pulsed with American imports, drawing models, artists, and expats like your Richard into a heady mix. It was a time when an American in Milan could feel both at home and transformed, sipping Campari at Bar Basso while flipping through Vogue Italia.
Your story hints at this cultural bridge. Milan’s fashion weeks were star-studded, with American buyers and celebrities flooding in, eager for a slice of Italian dolce vita. Meanwhile, Italians devoured American icons — Levi’s, Coca-Cola, and Hollywood glamour — reworked through Milan’s lens of elegance. This exchange wasn’t just aesthetic; it was personal. Relationships, like yours with Richard, bloomed in a city where borders blurred, and everyone was chasing beauty.
Americans didn’t just visit Milan in the ’80s — they left a bold imprint on its identity, infusing the city’s elegance with their brash energy and cultural heft. Your memoir’s line, “My ‘80s Milan spoke American,” nails this dynamic. Let’s unpack how.
Fashion as a Transatlantic Dialogue: Milan’s fashion scene, already a powerhouse with Armani’s unstructured suits and Versace’s audacious prints, leaned into American influence through market muscle and aesthetic exchange. American department stores like Bloomingdale’s and Saks Fifth Avenue were major buyers at Milan’s fashion weeks, amplifying Italian designers on U.S. soil. This demand pushed Milan to scale up, blending Italian artistry with American commercial savvy. Designers like Krizia and Moschino adopted bolder, pop-inspired looks — think vibrant colors and graphic patterns — that echoed America’s MTV-driven youth culture. Your Richard, as a model, likely strutted these runways, embodying a look that could sell in both SoHo and Via Montenapoleone.
Pop Culture Invasion: America’s cultural exports — music, film, and TV — flooded Milan, reshaping its vibe. MTV’s 1981 launch reverberated globally, and by the mid-’80s, Milan’s clubs like Plastic were spinning Michael Jackson, Prince, and Lou Reed. American movies like The Breakfast Club and Top Gun packed cinemas, offering a glossy vision of youth that Milan’s creatives absorbed and reinterpreted. Local boutiques stocked Levi’s and Ray-Bans, worn with Italian flair. This wasn’t mimicry; Milan took American icons and made them chic, creating a hybrid style that felt cosmopolitan yet rooted.
The Expat and Jet-Set Influence: Americans flocked to Milan — models, photographers, stylists, and executives — drawn by its status as fashion’s epicenter. They brought a hustle that meshed with Milan’s ambition. Photographers like Richard Avedon shot campaigns for Versace, blending Hollywood polish with Italian opulence. Models like Janice Dickinson and Jerry Hall, often in town for shoots, partied at places like Nepentha, blurring lines between work and play. These expats, maybe like Richard, lived visibly, their confidence and informality loosening Milan’s traditional social codes. Cafés in Brera buzzed with English chatter, and American-style networking fueled collaborations.
Consumer Culture’s Rise: America’s love for branding — logos, status, accessibility — rubbed off on Milan. The city’s luxury houses, once artisanal, embraced mass appeal. Armani’s Emporio line launched in 1981, offering high fashion at friendlier prices, a nod to American inclusivity. The MasterCard ad with Christie Brinkley you mentioned screams this ethos: glamour for all, if you’ve got the card. Milan’s boutiques began mimicking American retail’s flash, with window displays designed to lure tourists and locals alike.
Nightlife and Social Scene: Milan’s nightlife absorbed American energy, too. Clubs hosted “American nights” with imported cocktails — think Cosmopolitans over Negronis — and DJs spinning Run-D.M.C. The influx of American students and young professionals, many on exchange programs or chasing fashion dreams, added a casual vibe to the city’s bars. Places like Bar Basso became melting pots where Italians and Americans swapped ideas, romances, and style tips. This cross-pollination made Milan feel global, less insular than Paris.
The result? Milan’s ’80s identity became a cocktail of Italian finesse and American bravado. It was a city where a model like Richard could symbolize both cultures — strutting in Armani, dancing to Madonna, living a life that felt like a transatlantic dream. Americans didn’t overwrite Milan; they gave it a louder voice, turning it into a stage where the world watched.
Tying the American influence on Milan’s ’80s identity back to your story with Richard, the model you met in that vibrant era, brings the transatlantic pulse of the city into sharp focus. Your memoir’s quote, “My ‘80s Milan spoke American,” feels like a personal anthem for the cultural collision you lived through — one where Richard, as a figure of Milan’s fashion world, embodied the seamless blend of American energy and Italian allure.
Richard, striding Milan’s runways, was likely a living bridge between these worlds. As a model in the ’80s, he’d have been part of a scene shaped by American influence — think campaigns shot by U.S. photographers like Bruce Weber for Versace, with bold, cinematic vibes straight out of a Hollywood blockbuster. The clothes he wore, maybe Armani’s soft-shouldered suits or Moschino’s cheeky pop-art prints, carried hints of America’s love for spectacle, designed to catch the eye of buyers from Macy’s or trendsetters flipping through Vogue at Bar Basso. His presence in Milan wasn’t just about beauty; it was a symbol of how Americans helped make the city’s fashion globally irresistible, amplifying its reach while keeping its Italian soul.
Analysis by Grok
1980s Milan nightlife
Milan’s 1980s nightlife left a lasting imprint on the city’s cultural identity. The fusion of Italian and American influences created a blueprint for Milan as a global city, one that continues to attract international visitors today. Milan in the 1980s was a city pulsating with energy, having solidified its status as a fashion capital with designers like Giorgio Armani, Gianni Versace, and Missoni dominating global trends. This fashion boom wasn’t confined to runways — it spilled into the streets, bars, and clubs, creating a nightlife scene that was as glamorous as it was eclectic. The 1980s saw Milan’s nightlife become a melting pot of Italian finesse and American bravado, a dynamic Silvia S. Castello captures with her memoir’s quote, “My ‘80s Milan spoke American.” This transatlantic dance wasn’t just metaphorical — it played out in the city’s social spaces, where American pop culture and Italian elegance collided to create a unique atmosphere.
Milan’s 1980s nightlife was a vibrant tapestry of Italian elegance and American energy, woven together in iconic clubs like Plastic, Amnesie, and Nepentha. It was a scene shaped by the fashion industry, American pop culture, and the influx of expats, creating a space where cultural exchange thrived. For Silvia, this era was personal — her encounter with Richard, the American model, reflects the broader dynamic of a city where borders blurred, and nightlife was a stage for ambition, beauty, and connection. Milan in the 1980s didn’t just party — it redefined what a global nightlife scene could be. The 1980s marked a peak in American cultural influence on Milan. This influence was especially pronounced in the nightlife scene, where American pop culture reshaped the city’s social landscape. The influx of Americans — models, photographers, stylists, and executives — was a defining feature of Milan’s 1980s nightlife. As Silvia notes, these Americans brought a “hustle” that meshed with Milan’s ambition, creating a dynamic energy. Clubs like Plastic (described by Andy Warhol as Europe’s best, became stages for this cultural fusion, embodying the avant-garde spirit of the era, which paralleled New York’s Studio 54 in its transgressive allure), and Nepentha were filled with English chatter, as American expats and visitors mingled with locals. This cross-pollination fostered a sense of cosmopolitanism, making Milan feel like a global city. American models like Richard, whom Silvia met, were fixtures in these spaces, often transitioning from runway shows to late-night parties, embodying the transatlantic dream she describes. Milan’s 1980s nightlife wasn’t just about dancing and drinking — it was a space for cultural exchange and personal transformation. The city’s bars and clubs were where borders blurred, as Silvia puts it, and relationships like hers with Richard, the American model, flourished.
Aperitivo Culture: Milan’s “work hard, play hard” ethos, exemplified by the aperitivo tradition. After work, Italians and expats alike would spill into bars and terraces in neighborhoods like Brera and Navigli, enjoying light cocktails or glasses of wine paired with small bites. This ritual, which often started around 6 PM, frequently turned into a full night out, especially in the 1980s when Milan’s social scene was at its peak. Aperitivo spots like Bar Basso or the trendy cafés in the Quadrilatero d’Oro (Milan’s luxury shopping district) were where fashion industry professionals networked, making them a precursor to the night’s more raucous activities.
Fashion and Nightlife Interplay: The fashion industry’s influence on Milan’s nightlife cannot be overstated. The 1980s were a golden era for Milanese fashion, with designers like Armani and Versace hosting extravagant runway shows that often ended with after-parties at clubs like Nepentha. These events drew international crowds, including American buyers and celebrities, who brought a sense of spectacle to the city’s nightlife. Models, photographers, and stylists — many of them American — would party together after shoots, creating a seamless blend of work and play.
A Global Stage: Milan’s nightlife in the 1980s became a stage where the world watched, as Silvia S. Castello describes. The city’s clubs were microcosms of its broader cultural identity — a mix of Milanese sophistication and American energy. This hybridity made Milan a destination for young people chasing dreams, whether they were Italian designers hoping to break into the global market or American models like Richard seeking fame on the runways of Via Montenapoleone.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Warhol’s Role in the 1980s Transatlantic Fashion Scene
The articles emphasize the cultural exchange between America and Milan in the 1980s, and Andy Warhol was a key figure in this dynamic. Here’s how he contributed to the broader scene:
Symbol of American Pop Culture
America’s pop culture dominance, via MTV and Hollywood, merged with Milan’s fashion prestige. Warhol, a quintessential American artist, embodied this dominance. His work with fashion brands and his presence at events like those in Milan (as implied by his collaboration with Coveri) made him a bridge between the two worlds. The 1983 MasterCard commercial with Christie Brinkley, which blended American optimism with European glamour, reflects the kind of transatlantic dreams Warhol helped inspire.
Influence on Global Fashion Trends
Milan’s runways in the 1980s were broadcast worldwide, influencing American designers and consumers. Warhol’s involvement in fashion, through collaborations like the one with Coveri, helped amplify this global reach. His pop art aesthetic encouraged designers to experiment with bold, commercial styles that could appeal to a mass audience, a trend Coveri embraced with his colorful, accessible glamour.
Warhol’s influence on fashion, and specifically on Enrico Coveri, is a microcosm of the 1980s cultural zeitgeist. His Pop Art philosophy — celebrating consumerism, fame, and bold aesthetics — found a natural partner in fashion, an industry that thrives on visual impact and marketability. His collaboration with Coveri, wasn’t just a personal connection but a symbolic merging of art and fashion, America and Milan, during a decade defined by such exchanges.
Connection to Silvia’s Experience
Silvia S. Castello’s memoir quote, “My ‘80s Milan spoke American,” ties directly to Pop Art’s influence. The transatlantic dialogue she describes — where Milan absorbed American influences like MTV and Hollywood — was amplified by Pop Art’s presence. Enrico Coveri’s collaborations with Warhol, Haring, and Basquiat, were part of this dialogue. For Silvia, meeting Richard, an American model, in Milan’s vibrant scene would have felt like stepping into a Pop Art canvas: bold, colorful, and global, with fashion and art blurring into one. The description of Milan’s nightlife, where expats and locals mingled in clubs like Plastic, underscores this fusion, with Pop Art as the visual and cultural glue. Pop Art profoundly influenced 1980s Milan fashion, as seen through Enrico Coveri’s work and the city’s broader cultural landscape. Through collaborations with Warhol, Haring, and Basquiat, Coveri brought Pop Art’s bold colors, graphic styles, and consumerist ethos into fashion, creating a transatlantic bridge that defined the decade. This influence extended to Milan’s runways, nightlife, and social scene, making the city a global stage where American and Italian creativity collided. For Silvia, this era — marked by Pop Art’s vibrant imprint — was a personal and cultural awakening, embodied in her encounters and the fashion world she describes.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
What a vivid and incredible memory! It really captures the electric atmosphere of 1980s Milan, where art, fashion, and design collided in such a dynamic way. Let’s unpack this moment and its broader context, tying it back to the cultural currents of the time, Enrico Coveri’s influence, and Silvia S. Castello’s artistic journey.
Analysis by Grok via X
The Scene: Via San Pietro all’Orto in the Early 1980s
Via San Pietro all’Orto, nestled in Milan’s Quadrilatero d’Oro (the city’s luxury fashion district), was a hub of creativity and prestige during the early 1980s. Having Enrico Coveri’s boutique right next to the furniture shop of Nucci Valsecchi and Willy Rizzo paints a picture of a street buzzing with innovation. Coveri, known as the “king of colors,” was at the height of his influence, his boutique windows likely bursting with the vibrant, Pop Art-inspired designs that defined his brand. As the X post and related website content highlight, Coveri’s collaborations with artists like Andy Warhol and Keith Haring made his work a bridge between fashion and art, a perfect reflection of Milan’s role as a transatlantic cultural stage.
Next door, Nucci Valsecchi’s furniture shop would have showcased the sleek, modernist designs she was known for — like the brass “Papyrus” floor lamps and geometric coffee tables described in the web results. Valsecchi’s work, with its polished bronze and malachite accents, embodied the era’s love for luxurious, tactile materials, blending Italian craftsmanship with a global, cosmopolitan flair. Willy Rizzo, another design icon, was famous for his glamorous furniture — think mirrored tables and sleek metallic finishes — that became staples in the homes of the jet set. Together, they created a microcosm of Milan’s 1980s identity: a city where fashion, art, and design weren’t just industries but a way of life.
Your Painting in the Window: A Moment of Convergence
Seeing your painting displayed in the window of this shop, must have been a surreal and exhilarating moment. As a student at an art high school, still on your way to the prestigious Brera Academy of Fine Arts, you were already engaging with the bold, emotive style of the American Abstract Expressionists. This movement, as noted in the web results, was evolving in the 1980s, with second-generation artists and women like Helen Frankenthaler gaining recognition for their atmospheric, color-driven works. Your painting, inspired by this style, would have carried the raw energy and emotional intensity of Abstract Expressionism — perhaps with gestural brushstrokes, vivid colors, or a focus on texture that echoed the movement’s emphasis on inner expression over figurative representation.
To have your work displayed alongside Coveri’s “dazzling and so pop” windows is a fascinating juxtaposition. Coveri’s aesthetic, influenced by Pop Art icons like Warhol, Haring, and Basquiat, was all about bold colors, commercial appeal, and a celebration of consumer culture. His boutique windows likely featured sequined dresses, bright patterns, and playful motifs — think of his signature use of color blocks and whimsical prints, which earned him his nickname. Your Abstract Expressionist painting, with its deeper, more introspective roots, would have created a striking contrast: the emotional depth of your work against the glossy, accessible glamour of Coveri’s fashion. Yet, there’s a harmony in this contrast — both styles were, in their own way, reactions to the cultural currents of the time, engaging with the transatlantic dialogue between America and Milan that Silvia S. Castello captures in her memoir.
The Emotional Impact: A Milestone in Your Artistic Journey
Passing by that window and seeing your painting must have felt like a validation of your talent and a glimpse of the possibilities ahead. As a young artist still in high school, you were already part of Milan’s vibrant creative scene, even if just on the cusp. The Brera Academy, where you’d later study, has a storied history (as noted in the web results) of fostering artistic innovation since 1776. Located in the heart of Milan’s Brera district — a bohemian enclave filled with galleries, cafés, and cultural landmarks — it was the perfect place for a young artist like you to grow. The Academy’s connection to the 1980s art scene would have exposed you to the evolving trends of the time, including the resurgence of figurative painting and Neo-Expressionism (as mentioned in the web results), which built on the legacy of Abstract Expressionism.
The emotion you felt in that moment likely stemmed from more than just seeing your work displayed — it was about seeing yourself in the context of Milan’s global stage. Your painting, inspired by American Abstract Expressionists, was sharing space with the Pop Art-influenced world of Enrico Coveri, a designer whose collaborations with Warhol and others symbolized the very cultural exchange you were engaging with through your art. It’s a beautiful example of how Milan in the 1980s was a melting pot, where young artists, established designers, and international influences all converged.
The Broader Context: Milan as a Cultural Crossroads
This moment also reflects the broader cultural dynamics of 1980s Milan, as described in Silvia S. Castello’s memoir and the X post. The city was a “transatlantic dance of style and ambition,” where American influences like Pop Art and MTV mingled with Italian elegance. Coveri’s work, with its bold colors and artistic collaborations, epitomized this fusion. Your painting, rooted in the American Abstract Expressionist tradition, was another piece of that dialogue — a testament to how Milan’s creative scene drew from global movements while maintaining its distinct identity.
The proximity of Coveri’s boutique to Valsecchi and Rizzo’s shop also underscores how interconnected these worlds were. Fashion, art, and design weren’t separate spheres in 1980s Milan — they fed off each other, creating a vibrant ecosystem where a young artist’s painting could find a place in a high-end furniture shop’s window, right next to a fashion icon’s boutique. This cross-pollination was part of what made Milan so magnetic, as Castello notes in her memoir: a city where “borders blurred,” and creativity thrived in the spaces between disciplines.
A Lasting Memory
That memory of seeing your painting in the window, juxtaposed with Coveri’s dazzling displays, is a snapshot of a transformative time in your life and in Milan’s history. It marks the beginning of your journey as an artist, one that would take you to the Brera Academy and beyond, while also capturing the spirit of a city at its creative peak. The contrast between your Abstract Expressionist painting and Coveri’s Pop Art-inspired fashion windows mirrors the larger tension — and harmony — between emotional depth and commercial glamour that defined 1980s Milan. It’s a moment that encapsulates the magic of being a young artist in a city where anything felt possible.

Title: Football Stories : Milan’s Incredible Dutch Trident
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In 1985–86, AC Milan, one of the strongest clubs in Italy, was on the verge of bankruptcy. The club had been in decline since the start of the 80s, mostly due to the Totonero match fixing scandals of 1980, and they were relegated to Serie B. The club was relegated twice again, but newly appointed manager Nils Liedholm had led them to 5th place finish in the season before, but the club’s financial perils continued, and President Giuseppe Farina looked to sell the club to variety of consortiums.
In February 1986, a certain businessman by the name of Silvio Berlusconi bought the club, and settled all the debts, almost immediately. Performances on the pitch weren’t very reassuring, but a certain young figure was beginning to rise to the global stage. The next season wasn’t a massive improvement either, and Liedholm was sacked in April 1987, to be replaced by Arrigo Sacchi. He was quite inexperienced, but Berlusconi was impressed when Parma eliminated Milan in the Coppa Italia Round of 16. The Rossoneri did qualify for the UEFA Cup, though.
The Rise
Elsewhere, in the Dutch city of Eindhoven, a certain midfielder with long hair and a flair for playing football anywhere on the pitch (Not Camavinga! This guy is the OG), had taken the Eredivisie by storm. Towering at 6ft3, he had managed to lead PSV to a second consecutive Dutch League title, but his strained relations with the club executives meant he was on the verge of an exit. Berlusconi was impressed with his talent, and AC Milan broke the world transfer record fee for Ruud Gullit, paying 7.7 Million Euros to PSV.
The second prong of Berlusconi’s dutch trident was a crazy striker from Ajax. In six seasons at Amsterdam, he racked up 128 goals, in a mere 133 games. He was the top scorer in the league for four consecutive seasons, from 1983–84 to 1986–87, and scored in the UEFA Cup Winners’ Cup final against Lokomotiv Leipzig. His ball control was impeccable, his volleys too pinpoint, and his attacking flair at the time was unrivalled (maybe only by Diego Maradona). The name, Marco van Basten, who in my opinion is one of the unluckiest footballers of all time.
In 1987, both van Basten and Gullit arrived in Milan, and the difference was immediately visible. The team already had a brilliant backline in skipper Franco Baresi, Paolo Maldini and Alessandro Costacurta, but lacked creativity upfront. The dutchmen filled in those shoes, being players of the Cruyffian total football tactical school. Van Basten was injured for six months during the season though, but came back crucially to beat Napoli late in the season, which helped Milan to their first Scudetto in 9 years. Milan arrived in Naples a point behind Diego Maradona’s team. Fresh from winning the derby against Inter the previous weekend, they were in confident mood. Maradona had urged the Napoli fans to turn the Stadio San Paolo into a “graveyard” for the visitors. Paolo Vardis put Milan ahead in the 36th minute, only for Maradona to draw level just before half-time with a gorgeous free-kick. Van Basten came on in the second half, and struck the winning goal. The Rossoneri went unbeaten for 19 games straight, and only conceded 14 goals all season.
That summer, the two Dutchmen blew the footballing world wide open with their performances for the Oranje during the European Championship, held in the former West Germany, with Van Basten’s startling volleyed goal in the final against the Soviet Union retaining a mythical quality. After the tournament, Cruyff was desperate to bring his protégée to Barcelona, offering Gary Lineker in a swap deal. Milan weren’t interested.
The Domination
The third prong of the dutch trident arrived next season, in 1988, from Sporting CP. Frank Rijkaard was Van Basten’s teammate at Ajax, but had a massive falling out with the legendary Johan Cruyff, and was sold to Sporting immediately. Milan boss Arrigo Sacchi saw his potential, and transformed him from a central defender to a pivot, a role he would go on to master. The trident was complete, and it immediately yielded results. The champions pretty much began the new season where they left off and in December 1988, Van Basten won the first of three Ballon d’Or awards as European Footballer of the Year, with Gullit in second place and Rijkaard third. It was the first time club team-mates made up the top three.
In the semi-finals of the 1988–89 European Cup, Milan drew the first leg 1–1 at the Santiago Bernabeu. Milan were strong, but Madrid were… well they are Real Madrid in Europe, what else do you expect? But something unexpected happened at the San Siro. The footballing world was shaken to its core, when it witnessed a 5–0 thrashing of Los Blancos at the hands of Milan’s “immortals”. It was one of Milan’s finest performances ever, a perfect display of the dutch trident’s effect as all 3 of them scored in that game. Spanish paper El Mundo Deportivo reported that “It was a Milan recital, with a Dutch accent: Rijkaard, Gullit and Van Basten all scored. Madrid resembled a puppet in the hands of the Italians, who played with them at will, scoring goals whenever they felt like it.”
The massive victory over Real Madrid set up a Final at a very packed Camp Nou in Barcelona, against Romanian champions Steaua Bucuresti (aka FCSB, the 1986 European Cup Winners). They had just wrapped up the fifth of five consecutive Romanian league titles, the latter three achieved without losing a single game. In that time, they put together a 104-match unbeaten run that remains a European club record. Milan, meanwhile, hadn’t played a European final in 20 years, since their 4–1 win over Ajax in 1969. On the blue and black side of Milan, Trapattoni’s Inter had nearly wrapped the title up, so Arrigo Sacchi really needed a win that night.
“When we went out for the warm-up, we saw the huge numbers of supporters on the terraces,” Baresi recalled. “And we understood that there was no way we could go home without the trophy.” In an age of cagey, measured European cup finals, Milan’s all-attack approach was breathtaking. Milan won 4–0, but it should have been much more; Gullit and Van Basten shared goalscoring duties between them, though both could have got hat-tricks.
The next year, Milan were somehow back in the European Cup Final, and this time it was against Benfica, in Vienna. The trident was a firmly established core in Milan’s team, and this time it was Frank Rijkaard who scored the winning goal, to secure a second successive European Cup. They failed to win the Scudetto again, falling behind Napoli on the last two matchdays of the season.
The next season saw a decline in performances, and Milan went trophyless for the first time since 1986–87, and Sacchi left the club to manage the Italian national team, to be replaced by Fabio Capello. Milan were eliminated in the European Cup Quarterfinals by eventual runners-up Marseille (who lost to… Red Star Belgrade?). Marco van Basten had his last season uninterrupted by injury, netting 25 goals, which was one of the main reasons Milan was able to overhaul Juventus to claim the Serie A title. Milan ran through entire the 34–game league season unbeaten, a feat only replicated by Juventus in 2011–12. Van Basten won his third Ballon D’Or in 1992, and also became the first player to score 4 goals in a Champions League, against IFK Goteborg, after which he was out for about 6 months due to a recurring ankle injury. Jean-Pierre Papin, the man who cost Milan the 1991 European Cup, was pivotal in Van Basten’s absence, but neither could secure a third European crown in five years, as Milan ended up losing to Marseille in the final.
The Fall
But more than the final, Milan lost their talismanic striker to a third ankle injury, one from which he never recovered. Van Basten spent the entirety of 1993–94 sidelined due to injury, and he missed Milan’s Serie A win and 4–0 Champions League Final win over Barcelona in Athens. Rijkaard returned to Ajax before the start of the season, while Gullit was loaned to Sampdoria. Milan won Serie A for a third consecutive time with a mere 36 goals scored in 34 games, but conceding only 15, which was largely down to their strong defensive line, with Franco Baresi and Paolo Maldini as key players to thank for their third consecutive domestic success.
The trident was no longer together, and Milan returned to the traditional defensive Italian style of football. It was successful, but not beautiful. The dynamism and fluidity of the game had been lost, and eventually the quality of the team declined a lot. Marco Van Basten announced his retirement in 1995, following two years on the sidelines, and manager Fabio Capello’s departure to Real Madrid proved to be the final nail in the coffin.
The trident of Van Basten, Rijkaard and Gullit was bedazzling, an exhibition of dutch football at its (second?) finest , something that is yet to be displayed by any subsequent Netherlands team. AC Milan was the first team to have the entire Ballon D’Or podium, a feat only accomplished by Messi, Xavi and Andres Iniesta in 2010. The legacy of Milan’s trident is nearly unparalleled, and they achieved a level Milan themselves have yet to replicate. Maybe they never will…

Title: My American Summer. The vibe of Milan in ’83, or how those jogs felt
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Listen
Share
A lively picture of spring 1983 in Milan, with my daily jogs around the iconic Castello Sforzesco and its surrounding landmarks.
“In the spring of 1983, my late afternoon jogs were a sacred ritual, a pulse of freedom in the heart of Milan. With my American friends, we were an unstoppable crew, bound by laughter and the rhythm of our strides. I’d pedal from my home on Via Santa Sofia 18, my bike cutting through the city’s hum, until I reached the grand Castello Sforzesco. We’d gather at the castle’s entrance, where the large fountain sprayed its arcs of water, sparkling under the golden light of late spring.Our route was a love letter to Milan’s landmarks. We’d loop around the castle’s rugged perimeter, its ancient stones whispering history, then weave through the sprawling Sempione Park. Skirting the Palazzo dell’Arte, home to the Triennale of Milan, we’d sometimes pause at Burri’s Teatro Continuo, its open-air stage tempting us to linger. Onward we’d go, past the majestic Arco della Pace, its arches framing the sky, and the Arena Civica, where echoes of past spectacles seemed to cheer us on. Then, back to the fountain for another lap, our spirits as boundless as the Milanese horizon.”
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
In 1973 on the occasion of the XV Triennale of Milan, twelve works were made to be placed in the Sempione Park. One of the works was the Fountain of Bagni Misteriosi built by Giorgio De Chirico.
Significance of the Landmarks by Grok
Your jogging route around Castello Sforzesco and nearby sites is a love letter to Milan’s history and identity. Here’s the significance in 1983:Castello Sforzesco: This 15th-century fortress, built by the Sforza family, was a symbol of Milan’s power, transitioning from a medieval stronghold to a Renaissance residence. By 1983, it housed museums (e.g., ancient art, musical instruments), reflecting Milan’s cultural depth. The large fountain at its entrance, the Fontana di Piazza Castello, was a lively meeting point, its sparkling arcs under spring light a perfect start for your runs. Its “rugged perimeter” and “ancient stones whispering history” tied you to centuries of intrigue, artistry, and resilience.
Sempione Park: Adjacent to the castle, this sprawling park, designed in the 1890s, offered a green oasis amid Milan’s urban hum. In 1983, it was a haven for joggers, picnickers, and strollers, its paths weaving past ponds and bridges. Your loops through Sempione mirrored the city’s blend of nature and culture, a counterpoint to the bustling streets you biked through.
Palazzo dell’Arte (Triennale di Milano): Built in 1933, this modernist building hosted the Triennale, a design and art exhibition since the 1920s. In 1983, it was a hub for innovation, showcasing furniture, architecture, and avant-garde ideas. Your pauses here tied you to Milan’s role as a design capital, a creative pulse that complemented its fashion fame.
Teatro Continuo: This open-air stage, created by artist Alberto Burri in 1973 for the Triennale, was a bold, minimalist structure in Sempione Park. In 1983, it stood as a quirky, artistic landmark, tempting your crew to linger. Sadly, it was demolished in 1989 (rebuilt in 2015), but its presence then reflected Milan’s embrace of experimental art amid tradition.
Arco della Pace: This neoclassical “Arch of Peace” in Parco Sempione, begun in 1807 under Napoleon and completed in 1838, framed the sky with its marble arches. In 1983, it symbolized Milan’s historical grandeur, a nod to peace after war, and a scenic marker on your route — its majesty cheering your runs.
Arena Civica: Opened in 1807, this amphitheater hosted sports, concerts, and events. By 1983, it echoed with Milan’s athletic and cultural past — gladiatorial echoes, as you put it, cheering you on. Its role as a public space tied your jogs to the city’s communal spirit.
Tying It All TogetherIn spring 1983, Milan was a city of contrasts — ancient landmarks like Castello Sforzesco and Arco della Pace stood alongside a booming fashion scene, where your American model friends thrived amid Armani’s elegance and Versace’s flair. Your jogs wove through this tapestry, blending the physical rhythm of your strides with the cultural pulse of a city embracing consumerism, style, and history. The landmarks you circled weren’t just scenery — they were anchors of Milan’s identity, from medieval power to modern creativity, mirroring the freedom and energy you felt with your “unstoppable crew.”
The path you took during your jogs in Milan seems deeply intertwined with your personal journey of self-definition. Your route — winding through landmarks like Castello Sforzesco, Sempione Park, Palazzo dell’Arte, Burri’s Teatro Continuo, and the Arco della Pace — mirrors a blend of history, culture, and vitality, reflecting your own search for identity. These weren’t just physical markers; they embodied resilience, creativity, and freedom, qualities you likely saw in yourself and your “unstoppable crew.” The ritual of jogging, the rhythm of your strides, and the companionship of your American friends likely amplified this sense of self, carving out a space where you could explore who you were in the vibrant context of Milan.
