Title: My Trip To Milan Was Almost Ruined
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Adventures and misadventures as we travel the world. Are you a traveller looking for a home for your stories? Your true travel stories are welcome. Ask to become a writer.

Featured
--
6
Listen
Share
Working as a fashion forecaster, I decided a trip to Milan would give me some inspiration for my clients.
I’m rather bohemian when it comes to my own style of clothing. More Janis Joplin crossed with Jimi Hendrix and a touch of Keith Richards than Audrey Hepburn.
However, I had carefully curated a capsule wardrobe with an assortment of elegant, high-quality clothes with designer labels for times like these.
I was looking forward to elevating my look for a few days. My dreadlocks would be hidden under a selection of colourful turbans, and I chose my favourite Givenchy jacket to wear for the journey.
I wanted to create the right impression as soon as I entered the hotel.
I couldn’t decide which handbag to accompany my outfits and eventually settled for a Vivienne Westwood because her bags are like the Tardis.
I felt rather special for a change as I admired each outfit in the bedroom mirror before packing it into my suitcase.
I was all set to go,
classy shoes, check.
An assortment of elegant suits and dresses, check.
Handbags, jackets, and accessories check.
Fashion capital of the world, here I come..
The day before my flight, I had a thorough clean around the house, dusting and mopping all the floors. It’s always nice to walk back into a tidy home after a trip away. It gives you that glad to be home feeling.
Everything was going well until I dropped a heavy glass paperweight on my foot.
The paperweight is antique and incredibly heavy with sharp edges. Immediately, I heard my toe pop.
I knew in an instant that the toe was broken as I tried to stop the blood flow and keep it elevated.
A few hours later, I tried a pair of shoes on, but it was useless.
My foot was swelling, and I was due at the airport in the early hours of the morning.
I had to choose, either cancel the vacation or strap my toe up and soldier on.
I decided on the latter because I had looked forward to visiting Milan for months.
It was far too painful to bandage my toe, so I decided to let the air get to it and hope for the best.
I tried on various shoes, trainers, and mules, but I just couldn’t cope with anything touching my toe.
So, out of the suitcase came the flattering heels and in went a pair of old fluffy, pink slippers.
The only item of footwear that would go anywhere near my injured foot apart from a battered pair of flip flops for nipping outside to the dustbin.
The moment of departure arrived, and I tried to manage the tedious journey of buses, trains, and planes wearing flip flops.
It was very painful. My toe was throbbing and in-between my toes bled where they were rubbing the skin.
Eventually, I arrived in Milan.
It was raining heavily, and as soon as I had stepped off the coach, I stood in a huge puddle.
Tired and sore with a heavy suitcase, I managed to limp into my hotel, looking like someone out of Fraggle Rock.
I’d forgotten about piling my long red locks into a pretty turban and felt like a hot mess.
This was not the impression I had been hoping to make.
I tried convincing myself that my toe would feel better tomorrow, and I would not be visiting The Last Supper in wet fluffy pink slippers.
I went to sleep with my gigantic toe poking out of the quilt like a Belisha beacon and my soggy slippers drying on the heater.
The following morning, I got up early to take a tram, but my foot was now a nice shade of black and blue, I applied some cream to help with the bruising and got myself dressed.
I was kitted out from head to toe in a smart plaid outfit made from high-quality fabric. I paired this with a designer handbag and worn, misshapen pink fluffy slippers, which the dogs lay on when they were pining for me.
I told myself “no one will care.”
I hobbled out of the hotel, barely able to walk on one foot and made my way to the tram stop.
Everyone was looking at me, and I was very wrong. They certainly did care.
Apparently, footwear is the most important part of putting together an outfit for the Italians, and I was getting some very peculiar looks.
I felt very self-conscious as I noticed people’s eye’s automatically drawn to my feet, accompanied by a mixture of distasteful looks and sniggers.
I must have looked a sight trying to keep up with my tour guide.
I soon forgot my predicament when I saw The Last Supper.
The fresco took me by surprise, and I was enchanted at how it had stood the test of time. I sat for a while, taking in the scene alone with my thoughts..
The point of my trip was to gain inspiration for putting together a budget version of the latest trends for my clients. The next stop was the designer boutiques for a few photo opportunities and a spot of people watching.
Walking along the Via Montenapoleone, I felt slightly nauseous. The slippers were now stretched out of shape, and I was struggling to keep them on.
The pain was almost unbearable, and by this point, my mood was rather low.
I was beginning to resent people who judge others so harshly based on their appearance.
I wondered why I hadn’t just cancelled the trip instead of hoping for a miraculous recovery. I was fed up with all the sniggers off passers-by, and I was aware of how ridiculous I looked.
I decided to abandon the idea of wandering around plush designer boutiques for the moment and treat myself to a couple of cocktails overlooking the Duomo.
I was grateful for an Aperol Spritz or two and the opportunity to sit for a while admiring the wonderful view.
The Duomo is breathtakingly beautiful.
I thought to myself what a fantastic experience it would be to go to the top of it and see the views over Milan.
I finished my drink and limped across the busy square. A tour guide told me there was an elevator to take tourists up to the top of the Duomo.
I was very excited, I queued for the elevator and couldn’t wait to experience the amazing skyline of Milan in the sunshine.
As soon as I reached the top, I felt slightly wobbly, but I was glad that I had taken the decision to do it. The views from different parts of the rooftop were incredible.
I decided to head back down and have a bite to eat before attempting to walk along the busy streets,observing the beautiful people of Milan in their full glory once again.
I asked where the elevator was and was told there wasn’t one for going back down. I gulped and began the arduous walk down the narrow, twisting steps.
It seemed to take ages, I peered out of each little window to see how far I’d got but never seemed to be getting any further near ground level.
Eventually, I was back in the square and happily tucking into a delicious pasta dish with the finest coffee I’d ever tasted.
After lunch and a rest, I set off once more, dragging my body along the streets amongst the wealthy shoppers carrying their purchases in fancy bags.
The window displays were very eye-catching, but the pavements needed a bit of attention. I was also slightly surprised by the amount of graffiti everywhere.
People of all ages graced the streets, showcasing their most outrageous and most decadent styles.
It was a sight to behold.
I observed a few ideas that I might be able to recreate for my clients. I took note of what the latest fashion trends are and how to pair outfits together with various accessories and jewellery to give them a certain ‘je ne sais quoi’.
I would be able to source a selection of ethical, conscious garments from local thrift shops to put together the same look for a fraction of the price.
I took a few snapshots of the area for my son, who is at an age where labels on clothing matter and then decided to head back to my hotel.
The following days were pleasant, and gradually, my painful toe began to feel slightly better.
I particularly loved visiting the spectacular churches.
I enjoyed the evenings, sipping coffee and listening to the musicians playing in the square whilst admiring the Duomo. It looked very atmospheric when the lights came on.
I peered down at my slippers as if to thank them for their loyalty and for helping me to negotiate the cobbled streets without tripping over.
How I had looked forward to being part of the in crowd in my tailored suits and glamorous footwear. I smiled at the realisation that perhaps this had all been a lesson.
I wasn’t being authentic in the expensive, fashionable capsule wardrobe I’d carefully put together. I’m an old hippie at heart.
I love bangles, beads, and flowing maxi dresses. The feeling of freedom and individuality, not afraid to be different from the crowd.
I don’t fit in with the people who only wear the latest trends.
I finished my coffee and made my way back to the courtyard of my hotel.
One last Aperol Spritz for the road and then back home to my two dogs tomorrow.
They can keep my pink fluffy slippers, I don’t think I’ll be wearing them again…
--

Title: Milan
Content:

David
Our fleeting eye contact overwhelms me as you dance topless before me. I sit alone, front row center, while other customers slouch distracted in dark corners.
Does staring into your eyes make you uncomfortable? Would you prefer I watch your breasts? The diamond in your navel? The curve of your back? I’d understand — it’s less intimate than holding your gaze.
Monday night, nearly closing. Three men nurse drinks without looking up from their phones. You move under harsh lights, but when our eyes meet, your performance transforms. Becomes intentional.
I came here running from Sarah’s absence — six weeks of silence echoing through my apartment. Thought paying for attention might ease the ache. Instead, watching you navigate between performance and truth, I’ve found something deeper.
You step closer, near enough that I catch your scent beneath the club’s stale air. Your eyes ask questions I can’t answer, searching my face like you’re trying to solve a puzzle. There’s vulnerability in how you tilt your head, curiosity in your expression.
You gesture toward the bar with raised eyebrows — an invitation that feels more like a lifeline than transaction. Two isolated souls finding unexpected recognition.
Milan
This one’s different. Sits front row but watches my face, not my body. Makes me nervous in ways I’d forgotten possible.
Most men here want fantasy — the girlfriend experience without emotional cost. They stare at my breasts, my ass, the diamond piercing my navel. Safe objectification that keeps distance between who I am and what I do.
But he meets my eyes. Holds them. Makes this feel less like performance, more like… what? Connection? Dangerous thinking for a Tuesday shift.
His loneliness radiates like heat. Recent breakup, probably — I recognize the hollow look. Usually I’d exploit that, milk sympathy for extra tips. But something stops me. Maybe how his stare lacks hunger, contains only recognition.
I move closer, testing boundaries. He doesn’t leer or make crude gestures. Just watches with an intensity that should feel invasive but doesn’t. Like he sees through the costume, the makeup, straight to whoever I was before this.
When I gesture toward the bar, he nods immediately. Not calculating cost or anticipating service — just accepting invitation.
I finish my set mechanically, mind elsewhere. Been dancing three years, perfected the art of emotional distance. But this stranger’s gaze has cracked something open. Made me remember what it felt like to be seen as human rather than commodity.
Two more songs, then I’ll discover if this moment means what it feels like — or if I’m just another lonely person mistaking transaction for connection

Milan, located in northern Italy, embodies not just a city but a way of life.
This city offers its guests an unforgettable experience, flawlessly mixing cultural themes like history, art, fashion, and food at every turn.
Morning Ritual in the Heart of the Duomo.
The rhythm of Milan starts with the first light of morning at the Duomo di Milano.
This Gothic masterpiece combines faith-filled prayers from the past with ambitious architectural visions for the future.
The cathedral’s white marble facade sparkles like a sea of light at daybreak.Looking down on the city from the terraces, you can sense Milan’s ageless dynamism.
This edifice is more than simply an architectural wonder; it is the spirit of the city, with each column and figure evoking Milan’s magnificent history.

Milan is more than simply a city rich in history; it is also a master who celebrates art in a timeless way.

Title: Milan Design Week

I didn’t go to Salone del Mobile. But I consumed it. For me, April unfolded like a mirage, not in the palazzos or streets of Milan, but across the digital pages of magazines, in well crafted essays, reflective recaps, the feeds of design influencers, and the glow of late-night Instagram scrolls. I found myself wading through a never-ending cascade. Yet what struck me was the peculiar duality of my experience. I was simultaneously closer to Milan Design Week, and yet fundamentally disconnected from what makes this annual pilgrimage essential for so many in our field.
My understanding of this year’s Salone del Mobile, like every other year, was shaped by what editors at Dezeen, Wallpaper, Archdaily and others deemed significant — a curated lens that both reveals and conceals. This digital rendering made me think of what we gain and lose when design culture translates to screens. The democratisation of access is undeniable; no longer is attendance contingent upon financial privilege, professional connections, or geographic convenience. And yet, what does it mean to “experience” design through the flattened interface of a screen, mediated by the curatorial decisions of editors, social media managers, PR and marketing teams?
Dezeen’s “Ten enviable apartments unlocked for Milan design week,” illuminated precisely what was missing: a sense of wanderlust that comes from moving through spaces not normally accessible to the public. Photographs, however expertly composed, cannot convey the volumetric reality of these grand rooms, the dialogue between objects and their settings, or the phenomenological experience of presence. What I could also not experience was the warmth of the Milanese sun; casual conversations with strangers in the palazzo; the stir in emotions and spiritual angst with Robert Wilson presentation of “Mother”; the smell of espresso lingering in spaces; the bodily fatigue that comes from hours of walking and waiting in the queues. I kept returning to this list, as if something else was amiss.
Despite its incompleteness, this digital experience offered a certain sense of liberation. I moved from installation to installation, lists to lists, and stories to stories with effortless clicks, guided not by distances but by algorithms and curatorial decisions of magazines. I was able to move, at a contemplative pace, between Benjamin Hubert’s 101010 collection — which Eric Mutrie of Azure Media aptly puts as, “strive to do nothing less than solve the world’s problems,” — to Yatzer’s Costas Voyatzis’ piece on SaloneSatellite’s New Craftsmanship: A New World, highlighting materials, technologies, and social concerns that are quietly shaping the next chapter of design itself, and Alcova’s newest sites: the former SNIA Factory and the Pasino Glasshouses, where the juxtaposition of industrial decay and nature’s reclamation became evident. In all this was an experience both expansive and disembodied.
Amidst the listicles, reviews, PR pitched articles and fashion brand’s marketing declarations, what resonated most was Wallpaper’s Hugo Macdonald’s substantive interview with Maria Porro, the first female president in Salone del Mobile’s 63 years of history. Their conversation raised critical questions on the legacy and direction for Salone: What lasting impact does such a festival leave on its host city? How can Salone ensure that it remains accessible and relevant rather than becoming an exclusive showcase for luxury? Can it evolve from a business marketplace and commercial spectacle into a long-term cultural incubator for Milan’s creative economy? Perhaps this year’s edition offered some answers, with Es Devlin’s Library of Light, highlighting what it takes to engage the creative spirit of the community in a thriving city like Milan.
These reflections brought me back to something more fundamental: a question Max Fraser raised the year before: “is design increasingly moving away from addressing the everyday needs of ordinary people, and instead churning out a disproportionate number of decorative objects for the wealthy?” A single scroll through the abundance of displays underscores the concern — and perhaps this is where my digital vantage point offered unexpected clarity. Not being swept up in the spectacle allowed me to observe the excess and the imbalance with a degree of critical distance. Jack Murphy of The Architect’s Newspaper shared similar concern as he penned down his review. “How we can reduce consumption? How can we slow down? How can we create things that won’t spend centuries in a landfill or clumped in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch?” he asked.
As another global pilgrimage, Venice Architecture Biennale, opens to the public today, and London’s season for festivals follow, I find myself not just accepting but also questioning my digital vantage point. When I encounter these curated fragments through screen, am I truly engaging with architecture and design, or merely with its representation? Am I forming genuine connections, or simply collecting images? Even if so, am I missing out on the larger picture that perhaps one can hardly, if never, get from behind the screen? What hierarchies emerge between those who experience such an event first hand and those who, like me, get a peep through digital windows? I don’t have answers, only more questions.
--
--
London based architecture, design and travel writer.

Title: BRUTALIST MILAN VOL.1
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Milan is a city of contrasts, and brutalism embodies this duality perfectly: loved and hated, criticised and misunderstood, yet to me, fascinating in its rawness.
Its power lies in the material, in the boldness of its forms, in the honesty of exposed concrete that isn’t afraid to reveal itself for what it is.
My journey begins with Torre Velasca, an icon rising against the gray sky. I lift my camera and press the shutter. My focus lands on the barricades obstructing the view, while the architecture in the background dissolves into a blur. A technical mistake, perhaps, but also a sign. This accidental shot becomes the cover of my journey, a starting point that encapsulates the essence of my project: the dialogue between brutalism and time, between permanence and change.
I move towards Sant’Ambrogio quarter, where the geometric lines of the Collegio di Milano stand sharp against the still air. Its edges carve into the sky, while the soft February light glides over the concrete, emphasizing its texture. Shadows stretch across the rough surfaces, deepening their presence. The atmosphere is suspended, the silence charged with meaning.
I continue to the Church of San Giovanni Bono, where spirituality merges with the brutality of raw concrete. The solid mass envelops the space with its solemn presence. I feel small before its towering weight, yet somehow balanced by the harmony of its forms. Every detail speaks of resilience, of a delicate equilibrium between heaviness and lightness.
Going back, I unexpectedly encounter a municipal building, a relic of a past era. The cracked concrete whispers tales of abandonment, of a quiet struggle against time. Though worn and weathered, its structure holds a stubborn dignity. I press the shutter as the sun begins to set, capturing the shadows creeping into its fissures. My film roll is nearly finished.
Finally, my gaze is drawn to TheTris — what I like to call “New Brutalism” (I know, architecture purists, it’s not the correct description). Here, glass and concrete intertwine, linearity meets monumentality, and the past blends with the future. It is the perfect closing chapter, a final destination that hints at a new perspective.
One last shot. The film roll is done.
Shooting on film is my way of giving these structures back their substance. The grain of the film merges with the roughness of the concrete, each imperfection becoming part of the narrative. Through every frame, brutalism turns into a story — an ongoing dialogue between time and space, between what is built and what is lived. An architecture that is eternal, precisely because it can decay, endure, and transform without ever truly disappearing.

Title: Out of the Shadows: Inter Milan’s Rise and Barcelona’s Fall
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Francesco Acerbi was never meant to be the hero. Not at 37. Not in a Champions League semifinal. Not after everything that he’s endured. But football, like life, doesn’t care about the scripts— only the moments. And in stoppage time at the San Siro, the man who once said, “Cancer saved me,” after battling addiction and illness, found himself alone at the edge of the box during this difficult period of his life. But with one strike, Acerbi scored his first-ever Champions League goal for Inter Milan — a goal that didn’t just save his team from collapse but completed a story that defied odds far greater than the sport.
There’s something beautiful about being overlooked in football or any sport. While the media was either talking about Madrid’s defensive issues, Liverpool’s injuries, Bayern’s dominance, or Barcelona’s stellar season, Inter Milan said nothing. They didn’t want this attention. Because attention is dangerous and Inter Milan knew that. All it brings is pressure, noise, and distraction. They simply waited — hiding in plain sight, working in silence, and building a machine that wasn’t begging for attention. And so, while the European Goliaths were busy announcing themselves, David was busy planning on how to dismantle them.
When the Champions League semifinal, they stepped into them like they had been there all along.
The first leg at Camp Nou was a roller coaster of a game for both sides. Inter made their statement within the opening thirty seconds of the game. Dumfries’ first cross was intercepted, but the second reached Marcus Thuram who managed to find the near post with an audacious backheel flick and a beautiful finish. The visitors lead 1–0, and the clock hasn’t even reached the one-minute mark. 20 minutes later the Dutch full-back Dumfries doubled the Inter’s lead with a stunning acrobatic volley and it looked like it was going to be a long 90 minutes at Camp Nou for the hosts.
But four minutes later, Lamine Yamal dribbled past several of Inter’s defenders before an extravagant left-foot finish that kissed the woodwork before landing in the net. In the 38th minute, the equalizer came as Ferran Torres struck it into the back of the net from close range. The hosts had completed the comeback.
But, Inter Milan quickly replied as Dumfries scored his second of the night from a corner in the 63rd minute to restore the visitors’ lead. Barcelona’s response to this was scoring the sixth goal of the night when a stunning 25-yard strike from Raphinha hit the top bar, bounced off it and into the net, via a rebound off the Inter goalkeeper Yan Sommer’s back.
The final whistle brought the thrilling and one of the most entertaining games of the season to a halt, leaving the tie in balance.
The second leg at San Siro was even more chaotic. The kind of match that had the whole world glued to their screens. Barcelona, chasing their first Champions League final in a decade, were expected to assert their dominance. But once again, it was Inter Milan who seized control of the game. Lautauro Martinez scored in the 21st minute following good work from his teammate, Denzel Dumfries. Then Hakan Calhanoglu converted a penalty, extending Inter’s lead to two. The noise at San Siro was loud. It was full of belief. It set the stage for a second-leg thriller that no one could predict.
But football never follows a simple script.
In the 54th minute, Eric García, a former Manchester City defender, volleyed one back for Barcelona. The game wasn’t over just yet. Then, Dani Olmo equalized for his team with his diving header in the 60th minute. The equalizer shifted the mood of Inter Milan’s camp from celebration to survival. Barcelona’s confidence surged, while Inter’s defenders grew tense. And in the 87th minute, Raphinha broke through and scored. 2–3 to Barcelona. It looked like the comeback was complete. The away fans exploded. The players sprinted to the bench. It felt like after ten years of pain and heartbreaking moments, they had finally done it. The final was just a touching distance away.
But this night wasn’t about the return of Barcelona. This night belonged to the team no one expected.
Three minutes into stoppage time, Dumfries was able to snatch the ball away from Pedri and put it in the path of Francesco Acerbi — a name you don’t expect to see on a scoresheet, let alone a moment like this. He was thirty-seven years of age. He had never scored in a European competition before. And yet, in a moment as important as this, with Inter’s season hanging in the balance, he struck the ball into the back of the net.
The stadium erupted. Acerbi sprinted to the corner, shirt off, tears in his eyes. As the Barca players fell to the floor, the Inter bench spilt onto the pitch. At that moment, everything that Barcelona had done over 93 minutes crashed within a matter of seconds. For Inter, it was the ultimate reminder that this game was truly alive once again and that it’s not always about tactics — it was about belief.
The hosts then proceeded to take the lead in extra time as Davide Frattesi curled the ball into the bottom right corner of the net. Inter knew that this was the game-changing moment of the match. They had the advantage. And by the time the final whistle blew, there was no question. Inter Milan hadn’t just advantaged. They had just put themselves in the headlines and announced themselves. Not with arrogance. But with a roar that echoed through San Siro and across Europe.
The strategic planning by Simeone Inazhghi deserved every ounce of credit for this historic victory. The rotational system — where defenders like Acerbi step up into attacking positions, and midfielders fall back to cover the gaps — had baffled teams all over Europe this season. Against Barcelona, it worked like a charm. It created space where there was none, and it disoriented Barcelona’s press, turning a traditional match into chaos for Hansi Flick’s strategic planning. The unpredictability of Inter Milan’s strategy was their greatest strength. It wasn’t just beautiful football. It was a brilliant strategy.
The semifinal wasn’t just a match. It was a reminder and a wake-up call. That the greatest teams aren’t the loudest. Winning isn’t always elegant. And that somewhere, lurking in the shadows, in silence, is a team that can change everything.
--
--
Football and Cricket enthusiast, writer, and creator of The Football Diary and The Cricket Diary. Sharing deep dives, tactical analysis in both the sports.

Title: Immortality
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
Milan Kundera, Czechoslovakia’s most famous novelist, passed away today, after a prolonged illness, at the age of ninety-four. As I walked into my library, where an entire shelf of his books confronted me, like children awaiting news, I could not but help feel distinctly uneasy. I felt like a mother, breaking bad news to a gaggle of awaiting children. I could see a change in the books, like a descending shade of pallor.
Milan, as I called him in the privacy of my room (he was not aware of my existence), has been a friend, a companion, and a person I turn to, for the past decade. I did not know of him when I was young. The first of his books that I read, was The Unbearable Lightness of Being, with a cover image of a line drawing of a dog, shaped like a sausage, or like a lopsided hat. The book reeled me in, like a fisherman reeling in a fish. And a great deal of my own insecurities regarding life and work may be laid squarely at the feet of this book. Milan, for me, and Kundera, for others, offers questions and ponderances, but never any answers. His characters act with a certain privileged detachment, their existences are not serious, but light. In a perverse world, where everything is pardoned in advance, where everything is cynically permitted, such characters make sense. They do not, however, offer solutions.
Milan encouraged my own, abnormal, ways of thinking. Looking at words, grasping connections and feeling the selfsame joy of discovery as of finding a new continent — this was his gift to me, and to many others too, I suppose. Looking at a copy of Ionesco’s Rhinoceros in the bookshop below Shreeram Arcade, and imagining a couple of young women with braided ponytails at the softie shop opposite, and dripping chocolate and laughing in short bursts , like staccato gunshots— I owe this image, and its memory, to Milan.
What is the relationship between a writer and a reader? Is it an intimate one? Does a writer teach a reader how to be intimate? I see mirrors before me, on all three sides, and standing on one side, dressed only in black tights and a black bowler hat, is Sabina. This image entices me, as I imagine it must have done for Tomas. Milan liked the idea of erotic friendships, that do not evolve into the aggression of love.
Milan occupied me for days on end with his untranslatable words — litost — to be distinguished from self pity. These momentary and yet extensive ponderances over suffering move me, to this day, and he keeps turning my eyes to other people around me, searching for their suffering. This gaze, which I have become aware of, for some time now, I owe to him. His treatment of ignorance changed my life, it changed my appreciation of time. I have become more withdrawn and more penitent, because of him.
Milan spoiled me, with his uncanny ability to turn a phrase. The struggle of man against power is the struggle of memory against forgetting — what a phrase! And what he is talking about is inevitability. Inevitability surrounds me — gravity : sand slipping through my fingers; time: sand slipping through the hourglass on my desk; decay: spots appearing on Karenin’s face in the cover. Man will always struggle against power, and fail. Memory will always struggle against forgetting, and fail. This moment will always struggle to linger, and fail. Failure, it seems, is not the end — not for Milan. He is aware of the methods of immortality.
For a decade, I have bought and read Milan’s books. Evenings beyond count have been spent on the quadrangle at Presidency College, talking about the right chronology to read his books. For some of us, Unbearable… would be the first. For others, it would be The Book of Laughter and Forgetting or Laughable Loves. Fourth on the list would be Ignorance, followed by Identity, Immortality, Slowness. Maybe then one of us would mention The Joke. Farewell Waltz, The Festival of Insignificance, Testaments Betrayed, Jacques and his Master — the list would peter off at this point.
These books — I have gifted them to friends, spoken about his work, about my life, using his words. Friendships have been formed based on these similarities, relationships have thrived and failed on these words, and all I am left with, is memory. Before/after photos for me have been spoiled forever, unless they involve a hat. I deem Milan responsible, and he is beyond my letters now.
A word to bid him goodbye — goodbye, adieu, farewell? I do not know enough to say adieu. I should stick to farewell. I never imagined I would have to say this word — farewell — to Milan. I imagined he would be here always — perfectly preserved, immortal. Farewell, from the imperative Middle English farewel, addressed to someone going away (fare you well), the German fahrwohl, the Dutch vaarwel hued in grief, the proto-Germanic far wela for a parting beyond the end of this world. Namarie in Quenya, Bidaay in Bangla, farewell, Milan. Farewell.
--
--

Title: Football Stories : Milan’s Incredible Dutch Trident
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
In 1985–86, AC Milan, one of the strongest clubs in Italy, was on the verge of bankruptcy. The club had been in decline since the start of the 80s, mostly due to the Totonero match fixing scandals of 1980, and they were relegated to Serie B. The club was relegated twice again, but newly appointed manager Nils Liedholm had led them to 5th place finish in the season before, but the club’s financial perils continued, and President Giuseppe Farina looked to sell the club to variety of consortiums.
In February 1986, a certain businessman by the name of Silvio Berlusconi bought the club, and settled all the debts, almost immediately. Performances on the pitch weren’t very reassuring, but a certain young figure was beginning to rise to the global stage. The next season wasn’t a massive improvement either, and Liedholm was sacked in April 1987, to be replaced by Arrigo Sacchi. He was quite inexperienced, but Berlusconi was impressed when Parma eliminated Milan in the Coppa Italia Round of 16. The Rossoneri did qualify for the UEFA Cup, though.
The Rise
Elsewhere, in the Dutch city of Eindhoven, a certain midfielder with long hair and a flair for playing football anywhere on the pitch (Not Camavinga! This guy is the OG), had taken the Eredivisie by storm. Towering at 6ft3, he had managed to lead PSV to a second consecutive Dutch League title, but his strained relations with the club executives meant he was on the verge of an exit. Berlusconi was impressed with his talent, and AC Milan broke the world transfer record fee for Ruud Gullit, paying 7.7 Million Euros to PSV.
The second prong of Berlusconi’s dutch trident was a crazy striker from Ajax. In six seasons at Amsterdam, he racked up 128 goals, in a mere 133 games. He was the top scorer in the league for four consecutive seasons, from 1983–84 to 1986–87, and scored in the UEFA Cup Winners’ Cup final against Lokomotiv Leipzig. His ball control was impeccable, his volleys too pinpoint, and his attacking flair at the time was unrivalled (maybe only by Diego Maradona). The name, Marco van Basten, who in my opinion is one of the unluckiest footballers of all time.
In 1987, both van Basten and Gullit arrived in Milan, and the difference was immediately visible. The team already had a brilliant backline in skipper Franco Baresi, Paolo Maldini and Alessandro Costacurta, but lacked creativity upfront. The dutchmen filled in those shoes, being players of the Cruyffian total football tactical school. Van Basten was injured for six months during the season though, but came back crucially to beat Napoli late in the season, which helped Milan to their first Scudetto in 9 years. Milan arrived in Naples a point behind Diego Maradona’s team. Fresh from winning the derby against Inter the previous weekend, they were in confident mood. Maradona had urged the Napoli fans to turn the Stadio San Paolo into a “graveyard” for the visitors. Paolo Vardis put Milan ahead in the 36th minute, only for Maradona to draw level just before half-time with a gorgeous free-kick. Van Basten came on in the second half, and struck the winning goal. The Rossoneri went unbeaten for 19 games straight, and only conceded 14 goals all season.
That summer, the two Dutchmen blew the footballing world wide open with their performances for the Oranje during the European Championship, held in the former West Germany, with Van Basten’s startling volleyed goal in the final against the Soviet Union retaining a mythical quality. After the tournament, Cruyff was desperate to bring his protégée to Barcelona, offering Gary Lineker in a swap deal. Milan weren’t interested.
The Domination
The third prong of the dutch trident arrived next season, in 1988, from Sporting CP. Frank Rijkaard was Van Basten’s teammate at Ajax, but had a massive falling out with the legendary Johan Cruyff, and was sold to Sporting immediately. Milan boss Arrigo Sacchi saw his potential, and transformed him from a central defender to a pivot, a role he would go on to master. The trident was complete, and it immediately yielded results. The champions pretty much began the new season where they left off and in December 1988, Van Basten won the first of three Ballon d’Or awards as European Footballer of the Year, with Gullit in second place and Rijkaard third. It was the first time club team-mates made up the top three.
In the semi-finals of the 1988–89 European Cup, Milan drew the first leg 1–1 at the Santiago Bernabeu. Milan were strong, but Madrid were… well they are Real Madrid in Europe, what else do you expect? But something unexpected happened at the San Siro. The footballing world was shaken to its core, when it witnessed a 5–0 thrashing of Los Blancos at the hands of Milan’s “immortals”. It was one of Milan’s finest performances ever, a perfect display of the dutch trident’s effect as all 3 of them scored in that game. Spanish paper El Mundo Deportivo reported that “It was a Milan recital, with a Dutch accent: Rijkaard, Gullit and Van Basten all scored. Madrid resembled a puppet in the hands of the Italians, who played with them at will, scoring goals whenever they felt like it.”
The massive victory over Real Madrid set up a Final at a very packed Camp Nou in Barcelona, against Romanian champions Steaua Bucuresti (aka FCSB, the 1986 European Cup Winners). They had just wrapped up the fifth of five consecutive Romanian league titles, the latter three achieved without losing a single game. In that time, they put together a 104-match unbeaten run that remains a European club record. Milan, meanwhile, hadn’t played a European final in 20 years, since their 4–1 win over Ajax in 1969. On the blue and black side of Milan, Trapattoni’s Inter had nearly wrapped the title up, so Arrigo Sacchi really needed a win that night.
“When we went out for the warm-up, we saw the huge numbers of supporters on the terraces,” Baresi recalled. “And we understood that there was no way we could go home without the trophy.” In an age of cagey, measured European cup finals, Milan’s all-attack approach was breathtaking. Milan won 4–0, but it should have been much more; Gullit and Van Basten shared goalscoring duties between them, though both could have got hat-tricks.
The next year, Milan were somehow back in the European Cup Final, and this time it was against Benfica, in Vienna. The trident was a firmly established core in Milan’s team, and this time it was Frank Rijkaard who scored the winning goal, to secure a second successive European Cup. They failed to win the Scudetto again, falling behind Napoli on the last two matchdays of the season.
The next season saw a decline in performances, and Milan went trophyless for the first time since 1986–87, and Sacchi left the club to manage the Italian national team, to be replaced by Fabio Capello. Milan were eliminated in the European Cup Quarterfinals by eventual runners-up Marseille (who lost to… Red Star Belgrade?). Marco van Basten had his last season uninterrupted by injury, netting 25 goals, which was one of the main reasons Milan was able to overhaul Juventus to claim the Serie A title. Milan ran through entire the 34–game league season unbeaten, a feat only replicated by Juventus in 2011–12. Van Basten won his third Ballon D’Or in 1992, and also became the first player to score 4 goals in a Champions League, against IFK Goteborg, after which he was out for about 6 months due to a recurring ankle injury. Jean-Pierre Papin, the man who cost Milan the 1991 European Cup, was pivotal in Van Basten’s absence, but neither could secure a third European crown in five years, as Milan ended up losing to Marseille in the final.
The Fall
But more than the final, Milan lost their talismanic striker to a third ankle injury, one from which he never recovered. Van Basten spent the entirety of 1993–94 sidelined due to injury, and he missed Milan’s Serie A win and 4–0 Champions League Final win over Barcelona in Athens. Rijkaard returned to Ajax before the start of the season, while Gullit was loaned to Sampdoria. Milan won Serie A for a third consecutive time with a mere 36 goals scored in 34 games, but conceding only 15, which was largely down to their strong defensive line, with Franco Baresi and Paolo Maldini as key players to thank for their third consecutive domestic success.
The trident was no longer together, and Milan returned to the traditional defensive Italian style of football. It was successful, but not beautiful. The dynamism and fluidity of the game had been lost, and eventually the quality of the team declined a lot. Marco Van Basten announced his retirement in 1995, following two years on the sidelines, and manager Fabio Capello’s departure to Real Madrid proved to be the final nail in the coffin.
The trident of Van Basten, Rijkaard and Gullit was bedazzling, an exhibition of dutch football at its (second?) finest , something that is yet to be displayed by any subsequent Netherlands team. AC Milan was the first team to have the entire Ballon D’Or podium, a feat only accomplished by Messi, Xavi and Andres Iniesta in 2010. The legacy of Milan’s trident is nearly unparalleled, and they achieved a level Milan themselves have yet to replicate. Maybe they never will…

Title: My American Summer. The vibe of Milan in ’83, or how those jogs felt
Content:
Sign up

A lively picture of spring 1983 in Milan, with my daily jogs around the iconic Castello Sforzesco and its surrounding landmarks.
“In the spring of 1983, my late afternoon jogs were a sacred ritual, a pulse of freedom in the heart of Milan. With my American friends, we were an unstoppable crew, bound by laughter and the rhythm of our strides. I’d pedal from my home on Via Santa Sofia 18, my bike cutting through the city’s hum, until I reached the grand Castello Sforzesco. We’d gather at the castle’s entrance, where the large fountain sprayed its arcs of water, sparkling under the golden light of late spring.Our route was a love letter to Milan’s landmarks. We’d loop around the castle’s rugged perimeter, its ancient stones whispering history, then weave through the sprawling Sempione Park. Skirting the Palazzo dell’Arte, home to the Triennale of Milan, we’d sometimes pause at Burri’s Teatro Continuo, its open-air stage tempting us to linger. Onward we’d go, past the majestic Arco della Pace, its arches framing the sky, and the Arena Civica, where echoes of past spectacles seemed to cheer us on. Then, back to the fountain for another lap, our spirits as boundless as the Milanese horizon.”
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
In 1973 on the occasion of the XV Triennale of Milan, twelve works were made to be placed in the Sempione Park. One of the works was the Fountain of Bagni Misteriosi built by Giorgio De Chirico.
Significance of the Landmarks by Grok
Your jogging route around Castello Sforzesco and nearby sites is a love letter to Milan’s history and identity. Here’s the significance in 1983:Castello Sforzesco: This 15th-century fortress, built by the Sforza family, was a symbol of Milan’s power, transitioning from a medieval stronghold to a Renaissance residence. By 1983, it housed museums (e.g., ancient art, musical instruments), reflecting Milan’s cultural depth. The large fountain at its entrance, the Fontana di Piazza Castello, was a lively meeting point, its sparkling arcs under spring light a perfect start for your runs. Its “rugged perimeter” and “ancient stones whispering history” tied you to centuries of intrigue, artistry, and resilience.
Sempione Park: Adjacent to the castle, this sprawling park, designed in the 1890s, offered a green oasis amid Milan’s urban hum. In 1983, it was a haven for joggers, picnickers, and strollers, its paths weaving past ponds and bridges. Your loops through Sempione mirrored the city’s blend of nature and culture, a counterpoint to the bustling streets you biked through.
Palazzo dell’Arte (Triennale di Milano): Built in 1933, this modernist building hosted the Triennale, a design and art exhibition since the 1920s. In 1983, it was a hub for innovation, showcasing furniture, architecture, and avant-garde ideas. Your pauses here tied you to Milan’s role as a design capital, a creative pulse that complemented its fashion fame.
Teatro Continuo: This open-air stage, created by artist Alberto Burri in 1973 for the Triennale, was a bold, minimalist structure in Sempione Park. In 1983, it stood as a quirky, artistic landmark, tempting your crew to linger. Sadly, it was demolished in 1989 (rebuilt in 2015), but its presence then reflected Milan’s embrace of experimental art amid tradition.
Arco della Pace: This neoclassical “Arch of Peace” in Parco Sempione, begun in 1807 under Napoleon and completed in 1838, framed the sky with its marble arches. In 1983, it symbolized Milan’s historical grandeur, a nod to peace after war, and a scenic marker on your route — its majesty cheering your runs.
Arena Civica: Opened in 1807, this amphitheater hosted sports, concerts, and events. By 1983, it echoed with Milan’s athletic and cultural past — gladiatorial echoes, as you put it, cheering you on. Its role as a public space tied your jogs to the city’s communal spirit.
Tying It All TogetherIn spring 1983, Milan was a city of contrasts — ancient landmarks like Castello Sforzesco and Arco della Pace stood alongside a booming fashion scene, where your American model friends thrived amid Armani’s elegance and Versace’s flair. Your jogs wove through this tapestry, blending the physical rhythm of your strides with the cultural pulse of a city embracing consumerism, style, and history. The landmarks you circled weren’t just scenery — they were anchors of Milan’s identity, from medieval power to modern creativity, mirroring the freedom and energy you felt with your “unstoppable crew.”
The path you took during your jogs in Milan seems deeply intertwined with your personal journey of self-definition. Your route — winding through landmarks like Castello Sforzesco, Sempione Park, Palazzo dell’Arte, Burri’s Teatro Continuo, and the Arco della Pace — mirrors a blend of history, culture, and vitality, reflecting your own search for identity. These weren’t just physical markers; they embodied resilience, creativity, and freedom, qualities you likely saw in yourself and your “unstoppable crew.” The ritual of jogging, the rhythm of your strides, and the companionship of your American friends likely amplified this sense of self, carving out a space where you could explore who you were in the vibrant context of Milan.

Title: two more days in Italy: Rome and Milan
Content:

Sign up

1
Listen
Share
I traveled through Europe, and I’ve been home a month now. Contrary to what I’d expected, my time away only made me more acutely aware of just how beautiful it is here… this little piece of California, where I grew up.
Not that the things I saw in Europe were any less beautiful. No; there, I saw things I could never have imagined, things that took my breath away with their utter unexpectedness and newness (oldness, really, but all new to me). But I think I’ve come back with a kinder, more appreciative eye. I got in the habit, while traveling, of perceiving the wonder in everything; now, when I look around the place where I grew up, I’m pausing more to reflect, to capture memories as if with a camera, and not forget.
Here, at home, the hills are a deep green this time of year; we’re starting to get a few of those summery days that are just barely too hot, but then perfect all evening long; children are riding their bicycles in the street and laughing like they can feel the school year coming to its end. The other day, I walked by a big Mexican bush sage, and the smell brought back a thousand memories of childhood, of playing in the backyard with my sisters long after dark, when we had our own bush of that sweet-smelling, lavender-colored plant. And as much as I adored my travels, much as I already can’t wait to go again someday, and hard as it was to leave, I did miss the context I have here at home: the memories that come with all the smells and sights and tastes. The memories of my life, memories of me.
And the truth, I found, is that one of the things I loved most about the lush greenery, rolling countrysides, and swaying olive trees in Italy was how much it reminded me of home.
•••
I miss Italy. I missed it as soon as I left it. It’s in no way very original of me; most people I’ve talked to who have ever visited there say the exact same thing. But there really is just something magnetizing about it to us American folks.
I set up my base in Venice and Florence, but did have the chance to see two other Italian cities — only for one day each, mind you, but with the impression they made on me, it only seems fair I give them their own post here. For one day, I saw Rome, and for one day, I saw Milan. Sometime — I hope sooner rather than later — I’ll go back to Italy, and make it much longer than just two more days.
•••
I almost didn’t go to Rome. I had long planned that I would take a day trip from Florence and make the pilgrimage, but found I loved Florence so much that I didn’t want to spare a moment from it. In the end, I tore myself away and hopped the train — because how can you go all the way to Europe and not see Rome? — and I’m so, so glad I did.
Rome is often called the Eternal City, and it is every bit deserving of such a grandiose name. As I walked through the busy downtown, observing the perfect coexistence of ancient ruins, modern buildings, and everything in between, I felt that there really was something eerily eternal about this place. Structures from 2,000 years ago stand as though nothing ever changed, utterly undeterred by the passage of time, the rising and falling of empires and regimes, the growth of a whole new society around them — or the nosy wanderings of tourists like me, seeking to get a glimpse into the heart of this place, what so many of us learn is the birthplace of our modern world.
First laying eyes on the Colosseum was surreal. The only thing I can think to compare it to, though obviously I have never had this experience, is that moment that astronauts first see Earth from space: a rush of feelings, mostly it’s real, and I’m really seeing this, and we really are so, so small. Because faced with something that’s survived two millennia, how can you feel any other way?
Of course, thinking of just how many people and animals died horrifically in the Colosseum, all for the entertainment of others, adds a whole other layer to the experience of beholding this long-standing and impressive place. I reflected a lot, while I was there, on our own humanity — are we really much better today? We like to think of history as being synonymous with progress, with always getting better, but we are certainly willing to excuse a lot of suffering from our fellow human beings, all in the name of being entertained, aren’t we?
But then, that’s another conversation, entirely.
As exciting as it was to see the Colosseum, stumbling upon the Pantheon — because stumble is exactly what I did — was even more bizarre. While the Colosseum, Palatine Hill, and the Forum all stand somewhat set apart from Rome’s main city center — preserved in their own sort of ancient “neighborhood” — the Pantheon is just right there, downtown, surrounded by restaurants, apartments, and businesses of our modern age. You would almost miss it, assume it was a replica or even just an especially pretty building, if you weren’t looking for it (and I was looking, and still almost walked on by).
If my hometown provides me context for myself, and my own beginnings, Rome gave me some of that for all of us—for humanity. Not that we all descended from the Romans, or that our forms of government and society were all influenced by them; rather, being in the Eternal City, seeing this strange marriage of the old and the new, brought me to reflect on — despite how young humanity is compared to most of the universe — just how long we’ve been here. Surely it’s been long enough now that there’s no excuse to still embrace the kind of violence that the Romans loved watching in the Colosseum. I hope that, the longer we stick around, we will keep trying to get better.
•••
It would be disingenuous of me not to admit the biggest reason I was determined to visit Rome, and it had nothing to do with ancient history. I have wanted to see the city for years because of a certain Romantic poet who spent his last few months, and ultimately died, there.
I was sixteen when I first started reading John Keats. Fascinated at that age by his beautiful yet doomed romance with Fanny Brawne, I upheld a thing of beauty is a joy forever (from his “Endymion”) as a life motto, and longed to write the way he could. I took a class on English Romanticism in undergrad and felt almost like I was “cheating” on Keats with how much I unexpectedly ended up loving Coleridge’s work; still, “Ode to a Nightingale” reigned supreme as my favorite poem (it’s still way up there). And since I discovered him, I’ve been troubled by his tragic early death, but I really could not have predicted how much visiting his museum in Rome was going to affect me.
It’s called the Keats-Shelley House — as it’s dedicated not just to Keats but to all the Romantic writers, including Percy Bysshe Shelley and Mary Shelley. The rosy-orange house stands, quiet and unassuming, right beside the Spanish Steps. When Keats began to deteriorate, his doctors sent him out of England to take the warmer climate in Rome, hoping that would restore him to health; he moved into this house in late 1820. He was dead in four months. He was 25.
When I first read Keats, at 16 years old, 25 sounded almost old to me. Now, I’m 25. And God, his life was only starting. Many scholars say that had he lived longer, he would have surpassed Shakespeare as the best and most prolific writer in the English language. He was a baby.
When I visited the museum, I got to see the room where he died. It’s small, with a fireplace, a desk, a bed, and two little windows, one of which overlooks the Spanish Steps. His illness did not deter him from enjoying the view, and he liked to look out at all the activity below, especially the bubbling clear waters of the square’s boat fountain (which is still there today). He died of tuberculosis, though his doctors resisted that diagnosis until the very end; and as a result, he was refused ample pain medication, and died suffering, terribly. That was really, really hard to learn, especially while standing in the same room where it all happened. I felt, suddenly, a little sick, and I wanted to cry, but I couldn’t.
But it isn’t fair to remember him, or anyone, just for his death. The museum does an excellent job of reminding visitors who Keats and his contemporaries were — that, though now they are all gone, they were once full of the gorgeous vibrancy of life, and created beautiful art that will never, ever die.
I learned that, despite the image we have today of a perpetually fragile and delicate Keats, he was a scrappy little guy in school, getting into many a fistfight before he discovered what good outlets reading and writing were. I learned how much he loved his siblings — he was the oldest, like me — and how much it devastated him when his little brother, Tom, died of tuberculosis at 19 (John had nursed him, as these were, of course, days before it was known to be contagious). I learned that, before he went to Rome to die, he charged his fiancée Fanny and his younger sister to always stay in touch, so they would have each other; and I learned that the two women did, and remained best friends for the rest of their long lives. I even saw a lock of his hair, and learned that despite my own vision of John Keats as a brooding brunette, he was, in fact, a towhead blonde.
Hardly anyone left that museum with a dry eye. It’s not easy subject matter, and they do an incredible job making it all come alive and feel real. But I left feeling hopeful, in a way, because what an incredible thing it is that so many people are still impacted by his story, and his art.
One older Italian woman, who was visiting at the same time as me, kept clutching her chest and rhapsodically saying, “oh, me amo Keats, me amo Keats.” I hope that, somehow, the wonder of the Eternal City allowed him to hear that, and to know how much he means.
•••
Perhaps knowing how reluctant I was to leave Italy, the universe conspired to keep me there an extra day. My plan to visit Bern, the capital of Switzerland, was foiled by weekend rail strikes on ItaliaRail, and I ended up stranded for a night in Milan.
It was quite the stroke of luck, because I absolutely loved Milan. More similar to Berlin than anywhere I visited in Italy, this city was like a hub of art, youth culture, and progressive modernity. I walked to the canal in the late afternoon to soak in the last light; there were young people smoking cigarettes atop brick walls covered in graffiti, and a street market full of vendors selling handmade gifts. I bought a pair of earrings for my sister, then wandered until after dark, trying to savor my last few hours here… this country I had come to love so much.
•••
Indeed, Italy was somewhere I had always known that I would love, but I guess I couldn’t have imagined how much. At the Keats-Shelley House, there was a list of American and British artists, writers, and thinkers who, at one point or another, made Rome their home, and it just went on and on. Longfellow, Dickens, Alcott, Browning, Copley, Ruskin. Keats, of course, though I know he must have wished it was under happier circumstances; still, he loved that view of the Spanish Steps, so much.
There’s just something about you, Italy, that inspires one to create, I think — and to make oneself at home. How else would I still be writing about you a month-and-a-half later, still thinking of you when I see my own home’s green hills, rolling countrysides, and olive trees?
•••
ROME
Activities: Visit the Colosseum and the Roman Forum (tip: plan ahead! the lines were excruciatingly long, and I didn’t have time to go in; buy tickets online so you can skip the lines). See the Trevi Fountain (tip: go in the morning, before the crowds arrive, or else you may have trouble even seeing much of that gorgeous, cool, clear water!). Go to the Keats-Shelley House and the Spanish Steps (this museum was so impactful and beautiful, and all in English; and the Spanish Steps are like their own separate world within Rome, just a gorgeous neighborhood).
My Best Meal: I only ate once in Rome, stopping in a little grocery and grabbing a salame and fontina panini. But let me tell you! That was one delicious panini. As with everywhere in Italy, there are a thousand restaurants every where you look and everyone is guaranteed to be amazing; wander off the main tourist tracks to find somewhere more affordable.
MILAN
My Hostel: QUO Milano / Cost: about 25 euros a night / Recommend?: Yes! Great common area, cute decor, nice room (we had our own bathroom, as well), and very affordable. It’s a tram ride from the train station, but all the main points of interest in the city are walking distance.
Activities: Go see the Milan Cathedral, walk by the canal, look closely at the street art, and talk to people (everyone was so kind in Milan).
My Best Meal: A Sicilian cannoli! One of the best desserts I had the entire trip. Stop into any given bakery as you walk the city, and I promise it will be delicious.
--
--

Title: The Lord of Milan
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
When listing major European football clubs, few people will fail to mention AC Milan. Sharing their famous old San Siro stadium with bitter city rivals Inter, AC have won the Serie A title 19 times and the European Cup on seven occasions.
The club is one of the biggest and most successful in the history of the game, and in 2024 it marks its 125th anniversary. Some of the biggest names of the game have been associated with AC Milan over the years, but perhaps the most important figure in their history is a man who you probably haven’t heard of- and he was born right here in England.
Herbert Kilpin was born in Nottingham on January 24, 1870. The son of a butcher, Kilpin worked as a lace warehouse assistant after finishing school. The love of football was developed from a young age, and Kilpin played for several sides in his hometown. In 1891, at the age of 21, Kilpin made the move to Turin, Italy.
Working in the Italian textiles industry, Kilpin was employed by Edoardo Bosio. A man of Italian and Swiss heritage, Bosio had connections with a lace manufacturer back in Nottingham. Whilst in Italy, Kilpin was able to play football and it was his involvement in the sport that gave him fame and notoriety.
It can be said Kilpin was inspired by Bosio, who founded Internazionale Torino, a club that is thought to be the first fully dedicated football club in Italy. Kilpin played for the club throughout the 1890s, and in 1898 he left Turin and made a home for himself in Milan.
By the end of the decade and with the 20th century looming on the horizon Kilpin, and fellow Englishman Samuel Richard Davies who Kilpin had moved to Milan, were preparing to become founder members of the club we now know as AC Milan. In 1899, the Milan Foot-Ball and Cricket Club was founded.
Kilpin’s first role was as player-manager, and the club didn’t waste much time in winning silverware. In 1901 AC Milan were crowned Serie A champions in what was only their second campaign as a club. The momentum of the club would be hard to stop, and Kilpin helped the side win the title as a player only in both 1906 and 1907- this would however be the club's last top-flight title victory until the 1950s.
At the club he founded, Kilpin spent nine years as a player and/ or a manager. Other clubs in Italy ceased to exist several years after their creation. Yet AC Milan started strong and kept growing. A powerhouse in European football, the club has humble origins and a lace manufacturer from Nottingham is a vital piece of the success-laden history of AC Milan.
Herbert Kilpin retired from the game in 1908 having married his wife Maria Capua three years earlier. Unfortunately, Kilpin died young aged just 46 in Milan, a city where thousands of passionate football fans are grateful to him now- so much so that he is commonly referred to by them as ‘The Lord of Milan’ with a wider group believing Kilpin to be the father of Italian football.
In 2017, in his native Nottingham, a shrine was created to Kilpin in the window of the butcher's shop on Mansfield Road where he once lived with his family. It’s a far cry from the raucous atmosphere of AC Milan’s San Siro, but it serves as a fitting reminder of what this man did for the beautiful game.

Title: Walking Through the Dark Side of Milan
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Milano, the city of fashion, of modern architecture and of mysteries. There is a Milan hidden from the main tourist spots, hidden underground, far from curious eyes and phone flashes. It is the city of skeletons, crypts and perhaps ghosts, if one is lucky enough.
The Milan of mysteries was a surprise to me, almost a shock considering all the skulls and creepy stories I encountered. Milan has a dark soul and nobody bothered telling me. My walking tour into the wild side started at Piazza Vetra. For this stop, I had to use my imagination but how could I miss the square of the sentenced to death and of the witches?
Nowadays, there are no more signs of this bloody past but until late 1700s the square was bloody red. There is an imaginary “bridge of death” connecting the two sides of the square: on one the prisoners were tortured and on the other, they were killed. When the deadly scaffold moved to another part of town, the square turned even redder -from the flames and the blood. In Piazza Vetra, the witches and heretics were burnt at the stake.
When its bloody history finally stopped, the square became an area where no one wanted to go, an area known for its crime. Until the city stepped up in 1996 and a renovation project has aimed to transform Vetra’s legacy. The Vetra building will revalue the green spaces of the square and it will open new offices and food courts, making Piazza Vetra a space for locals and travelers alike.
My walking tour of the Milan of ghosts continued to Ca’Granda complex, inaugurated one year ago with the opening of the cript and of the historic archive of the Ospedale Maggiore. The hospital was born as a place where the poor people of the city would go to seek respite from the plagues and more often than not, to die. It sat above the crypt and when the tour guide explained that, I knew we were in a cemetery.
Below my feet there were chambers of death, where the corpses were thrown to rot. Once, a water canal passed by the hospital and then remains spilled into the street, their decaying opening up more space for corpses. A trap-door opened into the chambers and I made sure to circle around it during the tour.
Recent investigations have found the bones of over 150,000 people and researchers are working on profiles of the poorest of Milan, their habits and their anatomy defects, often caused by the black plague. After imagining the worst scenes from the book The Name of the Rose (by Umberto Eco), the tour allowed me some air as we moved upstairs to visit the historical archive.
I had left behind the crippled, bloody and forgotten ghosts of the crypt and traded them for the ghosts of the noblemen. The archive includes big, ancient books (some dating to 1500) filled with medical records, from the monetary donations to the hospital’s holdings. The high, painted ceilings and the paintings of the philanthropists took me back to the cript. While poor people died without help, the rich got portrayed in expensive boots.
Those boots would have been perfect for this walking tour in the Milan of mysteries. One more walk brought me closer to my final destination but I had one more stop to make: the sanctuary of San Bernardino alle Ossa. The church has a small room with high walls covered in human skulls and bones, no joke. Simly, when the cemetery was full, the bones were moved to the chamber.
I had heard about this sanctuary but I had to see with my own eyes to believe it. The bones behind metallic nets, the ones clinging to the walls, the skulls used as decorations, crossed as the pirate’s sign while the painting Triumph of Souls and Flying Angels, the Holy Mary and figures of Saints look down. Perhaps in astonishment, like me.
Outside San Bernardino alle Ossa, the sun blinded me after the darkness of the chamber.
I walked through the Milan traffic and the crowds to reach my last stop in the creepiness walking tour: the Dome of Milan. Many churches in Italy are bright, with the colors of the glass windows reflecting on the pavement and with the golden of the decorations reflecting on the painted walls. The Dome of Milan is none of that.
Outside, it is candid white, but inside the darkness falls and on the roof stand spiky pinnacles and spires. There is even a sculpture of the dictator Benito Mussolini -although later on workers tried to make it unrecognizable, it is still there. Just like the Coro Jemale, a lesser know attraction beneath the asphalt and the traffic.
After four hours of exploring the Milan of ghost and mysteries, I got out in the late afternoon, surrounded by tourists, pigeons and perhaps, ghosts.

Content:
