Title: It’s all about Culture
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Last night I had a strange evening: Thanks to a friend — whom I thank — I had a last minute ticket for AC Milan’s last match of the season, in San Siro.
A mediocre match: 3 goals were not enough to win against the last team in the league, already relegated and without any ambition. Mediocre like the whole season, with results consistently below expectations and the continuous feeling of fragility (especially in the defense).
While we live this mediocrity, others win (congratulations to the nerazzurri of Bergamo, among others!) and it’s not pleasant. It’s not even comforting to remember the constant “favors” received, or the financial doping they benefited from. If we look at our own home, there is objective mediocrity everywhere: radical change was needed!
Furthermore, as if that wasn’t enough, the farewells of the team’s pillars, including the coach (and, worst of all, grim rumors circulate about not up to par coaches, who would have been chosen for the future).
With all these elements together, the evening was expected to be very sad and melancholic…
Yet, it seemed like a party!
It was a party!
We all experienced it that way,.. and it took me a while to understand what we were celebrating, then I got it: Culture!
The Culture of AC Milan!
Culture, the main element of everything. The most important “asset”.
It flowed everywhere: in the “Curva” with the explosion of smoke bombs in the second half, In everybody’s smartphones flashlights, in people dancing, getting emotional, in the farewell speeches of the coach and the most important players, who many rightly pointed out as the Moral Leaders of the Team.
It was, in fact, incredible: Celebrating defeat, mediocrity.
But, be careful: Not because this is the ambition, or because we settle for it. On the contrary!
The Culture of AC Milan says exactly the opposite: it talks about being, aspiring, always feeling the best in Italy and in the world. The Curva rightly emphasized that “THERE IS NO POSITIVE SEASON WITHOUT VICTORIES”.
So, celebrating defeat takes on another meaning, because human success, in individuals and Organizations, rests precisely on this invisible pillar and not on numbers, money, luck or even performance.
Success rests on what we feel inside as important, what moves us.
Upon reflection, even past successes were not born where it seems: the Scudetto two years ago was born, certainly in the Derby (“Si è girato Girouuud”, …) but also, especially, in the lost game with Spezia, where the players consoled the referee for a huge mistake that unjustly caused us a heavy defeat.
Or the Rio Ave,… And before, many years ago, in reacting to Istanbul before the triumph in Athens! And even before, the fog of Belgrade,… and many other moments.
It is in difficult moments, like this one, where you are forced to question yourself as a person, as a group and as an Organization, to understand what you are made of: what is your root, your Culture, indeed.
This is what makes all the difference. The rest, the performances, the results, will come later. They are just the fruits of this formidable root.
This invisible lifeblood that makes all the difference in the world, that creates your Identity, that makes you feel strong and proud, that is transmitted even when people leave and when others arrive, that transcends borders, passing within and outside people, groups, Organizations, involves players, formal and informal leaders and all fans, who are 100% part of it.
But this Culture must, indeed, be cultivated!
It is the most precious and irreplaceable treasure, because if you stick to it and fully develop it you become invincible (not because you never lose, but because you express your full potential), just like a tree or a human being in the course of their life.
But culture is a treasure not to be wasted, because wasting it would be the biggest sin!
For example, not having enough ambition means to distort this culture, to uproot it.
To make it something different, perhaps successful in the USA but not in Europe, where the show for its own sake takes precedence over the will to always excel, to win, would be to distort and uproot the culture.
In these hours, one cannot help but think of the choice of the new coach — an absolutely crucial role — for which the fans (#Nonseca and #Nopetegui,..) and all stakeholders have spoken: the names that come out in the newspapers are not up to this culture. What they mean is that this enormous heritage of Culture could be dispersed and subverted, and then even the basic economics and the entire structure of the Business would be put at risk.
There are countless examples, even in the same field, of how these factors are those that determine success or failure. Think, for example, of Atalanta, capable of winning the Europa League in a fabulous way, with a laughable budget, or Chelsea which, exactly the opposite, with pharaonic investments seems devoid of identity, spirit or — precisely — of Culture.
All this reflection on AC Milan and football cannot help but draw a parallel with the world of Business, where often we tend to forget how determinant these invisible elements are, and we dedicate ourselves — without great success — only to material or measurable aspects, such as Technology or Processes. But that’s another story…
Forza Milan, Sempre!
--
--

Title: 🌏 From Milan to Astana to Osaka: My Expo Journey Comes Full Circle
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
A New Chapter Begins
Tomorrow April 13th 2025, marks the grand opening of Expo 2025 in Osaka, Japan, and my heart is full of nostalgia and excitement. 🌟 As the world prepares to gather once again in celebration of innovation, culture, and collaboration, I find myself reflecting on my incredible journey with Expo 2015 in Milan and Expo 2017 in Astana. These experiences shaped my worldview in ways I never anticipated — bringing me closer to people, ideas, and cultures that continue to inspire me today.
My Expo story began in Milan, where I had the privilege of volunteering at the gates — welcoming school groups, elderly visitors, and guests with limited mobility.
What made this experience truly unforgettable wasn’t just the thrill of being part of a global event, but the people I met along the way. Volunteers came from every corner of Italy — and the world. Together, we supported visitors, shared laughs, explored the city, and formed friendships that have stood the test of time. 💬✨
One of my most cherished moments? 🎂 Celebrating my 23rd birthday with my fellow volunteers. It was such a joyful, heartwarming experience that turned a simple day into an unforgettable memory full of cannoli from Sicily.
Milan’s theme, “Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life,” set the tone for conversations around sustainability, innovation, and human connection. It was a transformative introduction to the spirit of the World Expo.
Drawn by the Kazakhstan pavilion in Milan, I felt a strong pull toward their message and energy. So, when the opportunity came, I applied for the volunteer program at Expo 2017 in Astana — and it turned out to be one of the most enriching chapters of my life.
Astana’s theme, “Future Energy,” echoed Milan’s message and created a beautiful continuity between the two Expos. I was immersed in a vibrant, diverse environment, working alongside volunteers from all over the globe. From helping organize cultural events to assisting at the closing ceremonies, every moment was an adventure.
What struck me most was how the Expo brought together people from all walks of life. Many locals were curious about where I was from, and that curiosity led to the most meaningful, spontaneous interactions. 🤝✨
I met:
We shared stories, posed for pictures (Search the Hashtag #ShotWidSid, a Humans of New York spin-off), exchanged perspectives — and in doing so, discovered just how universal our hopes and dreams really are. These personal connections were a powerful reminder of the Expo’s ability to transform individuals and strengthen communities.
Now, as Osaka opens its doors with the theme “Designing Future Society for Our Lives,” my heart is with every volunteer stepping into this magical experience for the first — or tenth — time.
An Expo isn’t just about dazzling pavilions and cutting-edge tech (though those are awesome!). It’s about curiosity, connection, and cultural exchange. It’s about stepping outside your comfort zone and embracing something bigger than yourself.
Even though I won’t be able to attend this year due to work commitments, I’m excited to relive and share moments from my previous Expo adventures — including behind-the-scenes memories and interviews I did with MTV Italy and local TV stations.
Me for MTV Italy
Me on local news:
To everyone attending or volunteering at Expo 2025 — Be curious. Be present. Be open to every encounter.You’re not just part of an event — you’re part of a global legacy. 🌐💫
Whether you’re guiding guests, sharing your culture, or simply soaking it all in — make it count. This is your moment to connect, learn, and grow.
And who knows?Maybe years from now, you’ll look back — just like I am today — and realize these were some of the most impactful days of your life.

Title: Best Food in Milan
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Shannon FitzGerald, Hannah Scholnick, Summer Spain, and Max Levy
Hannah: Gelato
Gelato in Milan is no joke. There are plenty of places to buy this decadent ice-cream replacement. There are three places I recommend as my top choices in Milan. My first choice is a chain called Cioccolati Italiani. Part of the reason I love this place is for the cone experience, not only are the sugar cones sweet and buttery, but before dropping some savory gelato into the cone, they line it with melted chocolate. You get a choice of white or milk — white was my favorite. So by the time you’ve finished devouring your creamy tiramisu, there’s a puddle of melted white chocolate waiting at the end of the cone, making each bite just as rich as the next. Aside from the cone, the flavors are very rich and well made, you get a choice of three different flavors for 3 euro. The flavors are not unique, but very well made. Another benefit to loving this place is that it exists in multiple locations, so it is likely there is one near you!
This is a link to the website and all its locations.
https://www.cioccolatitaliani.it/home/?lang=en
Locations in Milan:
Via San Raffaele
Via de Amicis
Niguarda
Naviglio grande
City Life
Cadorna
Bicocca Village
Malpensa
My second favorite gelato place is called Pave Milan. What is great about this place is its vast array of unique flavors — homemade of course. One of my favorites was Vanigla Sbrisolona — vanilla gelato with bits of cake mixed in. I also enjoyed the coffee cardamom, and their selection of refreshing sorbets. There was also one flavor that had bits of whisky in it — very good. My advice is to try flavors that sound strange, because you might be surprised. Aside from that, the staff was very friendly and they also served me free tap water after purchasing the gelato.
https://www.pavemilano.com/gelati-granite
My third favorite place is called Caldo Zero — Artisan Gelateria Caldozero and School Training. This place has an in-house gelato machine and a beautiful display of their rich flavors. This gelato was fairly inexpensive, about 3.50 Euros for a large, and the serving sizes were decent as well. Although the cones were basic, the gelato was so good that it didn’t matter! The oreo flavor was my favorite, and the tiramisu was good as well. This was perfect for a late night craving, and definitely delivered in terms of quality and quantity.
http://www.caldozero.it/
Max: Salads
Milan is typically known for its cocktails, risotto, and gelato, there are a few hidden gems for people who are interested in a healthier option. I found 3 places that will satisfy any salad-lover’s cravings .
California Bakery:
The California Bakery has a lot of options to choose from, including sandwiches, pastries, and smoothies, but I would recommend getting a salad! There are plenty of salads to choose from, such as Chicken Caesar and Chips Bagel Salad, but my personal favorite is the one called Salad Green and Crunchy, which has mixed greens are dried fruit. What I love about this place is its dedication to using the freshest ingredients, as well as its proximity to school!
http://www.californiabakery.it
Salad me Café:
Another great option in Milan is the Salad me Café located inside the Roman’s Club Gym at Via Giuseppe Prina. This place has multiple salad options for 10 Euro, all named after different cities in the United States! There are also heavier salads for 12 Euro, which offers salads such as Salmone and Veggy. Although it is a little pricier, it is definitely worth it to get a salad here. They use the freshest ingredients, and the salads will keep you full all day long.
https://romansclub.com/salad-me-cafe/
Salad House:
Salad House is one of my favorites because it reminds me so much of my favorite place at home in New York. The workers I met were even from New York! Salad House is amazing because you can choose greens and grains, as well as a cheese and three toppings for around 8 Euro. There are also some unique dressing options to add to your salad, which definitely makes it better. Salad House is located steps away from the Gemelli campus at Via Sant’Agnese 14.
https://www.tripadvisor.com/Restaurant_Review-g187849-d15110165-Reviews-Salad_House-Milan_Lombardy.html
Summer: Pizza
Pizza in Milan is a serious industry. Although pizza can be a pretty simple thing, here in Milan you can chose the dough, cover it with indulging ingredients, or even have it fried. There are an abundance of pizza restaurants in Milan, and it can be hard to know which to choose, especially when you’re on a budget. This is why I want to share a few of my favorite places for pizza, and explain why each is delicious and worth trying.
The first place I picked is Pizzeria del Ticinese. Now this place is perfect if you’re really looking for that typical Italian classic pizza taste and vibe. There is only appliance is a single pizza oven, baked on wood and of course, only made with the freshest ingredients. The atmosphere inside the restaurant feels very authentic and cosy. You are even able to watch them make your pizza and take it out of the oven when it is ready. The pizza is super affordable and it’s a great place for a quick bite.
Next is Briscola Pizzeria, if you are sometime picky on what you like on your pizza or just wanting to expand your taste palette, this is the place for you. Instead of having just one pizza, this restaurant gives you the options to have two mini pizzas.This pizzeria also lets you choose which exact toppings you want on your pizza, so you can create the pizza of your dreams! There are over 20 different toppings to select from and even have ingredients like pumpkin, which you can not find many places. It’s also great if you are with friends and want to share. A normal size pizza costs only 7 euros, and 2 mini ones together are 10 euros. https://www.briscolapizza.it/en/
Lastly on my list of recommendations, is Gino Sorbillo Lievito Madre. Here, not only can you get a real authentic Napoleone pizza, but the atmosphere is very inviting and a great place to dine with friends. Although you might encounter a bit of wait time until you are seated, it is worth it! Once you are seated, you are greeted with complimentary water and bread, and might I suggest a lovely glass of wine to go with the meal. There are many options of pizzas to choose from, as I just went for the classic margherita DOP. The ingredients are always fresh and the pizza is always cooked perfectly, and the prices are very inexpensive. Overall, I had a great experience finding delicious pizza that is freshly made and very affordable. I hope you find these recommendations helpful and are able to enjoy one of Italy’s great foods. Buon Appetito!
Shannon: Pasta
One of the main dishes visitors of Italy expect to find everywhere is pasta, and after spending some time in Milan, I can definitely say that they are correct! Although I haven’t been able to dine at every restaurant serving pasta, (unfortunately) I have eaten at a few places that I can surely recommend.
The first restaurant is a bit unexpected, because it is called the Pizzeria di Porta Garibaldi. This restaurant is perfect because it is located in the fun and exciting area of Corso Como, and the prices were very affordable. Their menu contains items such as pizza, risotto, veal, and spaghetti, but the best item on their menu is the gnocchi with pomodoro. The gnocchi was about 7 Euro and tasted amazing. The house white wine was also very good and inexpensive, which is perfect for any student on a budget. Pizzeria di Porta Garibaldi also offers indoor or outdoor seating, depending on the evening.
https://www.tripadvisor.com/Restaurant_Review-g187849-d2648160-Reviews-Pizzeria_di_Porta_Garibaldi-Milan_Lombardy.html
The next place that I would recommend is a slightly more authentic, and is called Pasta D’Autore. This picturesque restaurant is within walking distance from campus, and had the friendliest staff I have encountered so far! The lady who owns the restaurant had a full conversation with us in perfect English about her time spent in the States and about the quality of their ingredients. Everything is homemade in the restaurant every day, and it was easy to tell by the taste of the food! Another unique aspect to Pasta D’Autore is that each day they have a special long and short pasta of the day, as well as their sauce of the day. That is usually all they offer, so depending on which day you visit, you could get a different meal each time. I ordered the pasta of the day with potato cream sauce with speck and olives, while my friend got the other option of typical ragu sauce. Both dishes were amazing, and only about 10 Euros each! We are already planning our next trip back to try the highly recommended homemade tiramisu!
http://www.pastadautoremilano.it
In Milan there are thousands of restaurants to go to find amazing Italian food, but one of my favorites has to be Miscusi. There are three locations throughout Milan, we went to the one near Milano Centrale, but there is one near the Buonarroti metro stop as well. The food was incredible, but what really made this place amazing was the atmosphere — casual, but lively, with workers who were friendly and attentive! Every day they make their pasta fresh, and you can choose what to order by selecting a type of pasta, a sauce, and additional toppings such as cheese, vegetables, and nuts. The pesto was some of the best I have ever had! The prices were reasonable for the quality of the food, and depend on what you order exactly. My pesto with buffalo mozzarella as well as water and prosecco came out to around 14 Euro which is not bad at all! I will definitely be going back to Miscusi.
http://www.miscusi.com/it/
Overall, I have been lucky while trying to find affordable, authentic pasta dishes, and will continue to search for others to add to my list. The food in Milan is unlike anywhere else in the world, and if you are looking for inexpensive recommendations, then hopefully this will help!

Title: Milan: the invisible capital of organized crime
Content:

In The Global geopolitics, truth is one, but the wise interpret it differently.— Here, we interpret these diversions

Member-only story
--
1
Share
If you’re not a Medium member, you can read the story for free here.
When most people think of the mafia, they think of Sicily. Maybe Naples. Maybe a windswept hill in Calabria. Rarely do they think of Milan — Italy’s richest city, its financial hub, its face to the world.
And yet, Milan today is one of the most important operating bases for organized crime in Europe. Not in spite of its wealth, but because of it.
This is not the mafia of guns and blood. It’s the mafia of investments, logistics, real estate, and clean paperwork. It doesn’t control neighborhoods — it controls contracts. It doesn’t own shops — it owns companies that own shops. And above all, it doesn’t need to be seen. Because Milan, more than any other city in Italy, offers something priceless: respectability.
The numbers speak for themselves. In the last three national reports from the Direzione Investigativa Antimafia (DIA), Lombardy — the region around Milan — consistently ranks as one of the most infiltrated territories in the country. Not in terms of murders, but in economic presence. The ‘Ndrangheta, in particular, has been identified as the most active group, with well-structured families…

Design Now is a broad-framework program of open collective activities organized by Politecnico di Milano’s School of Design and POLI.design Consortium with the support of Polifactory, Politecnico di Milano’s makerspace, in partnership with Triennale di Milano.
This program aligns with the comeback of the Triennale di Milano International Exhibition, after 20 years. “Design Now” focuses on concrete experimentation in one of the main themes of the XXI Triennale: the mutation generated by technological advance and social change in the processes and know-how applied to the ideation and production of contemporary artefacts.
This year the program of “Design Now” included:
JAM “When Production goes into the city” focused on the relationship between service design and new production-distribution models, in collaboration with PACO design;
Summer School “Fab City: Designing Products and Services for Urban Resilience through Manufacturing”, which focused on selecting ideas and innovative experiences relating to urban resilience+manufacturing, in collaboration with IAAC and Fab City;
Exhibition included in the XXI Triennale’s program that will show all the process.
The main principles of designing in and for a Fab City are: 1. Design for liquid times 2. Design products with an urban strategy 3. Design interventions for constructive activism
The Summer School took place from the 8th to the 16th of July and tried to address big questions relating to the future vision of cities, based on three main approaches:
The program included lectures and visits in Milan to its Fab Labs and Makerspaces. However, the majority of the time was dedicated to designing products, services or product-service systems for FAB Cities, for urban manufacturing, and public and commercial services.

Title: Milan
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Milan is among the most populated metropolitan areas in Italy. The area has had human settlements as early as 200 BC and served as the seat of the Western Roman Empire. Modern-day Milan is an eclectic mix of historical architecture and skyscrapers.
Milan Cathedral
The epitome of Italian Gothic architecture. Milan Cathedral is an absolutely humongous yet gorgeous building. The scale and beauty, for lack of better words, blows you away. Construction began in 1386 and officially finished only in 1965. That is 600 years to build it, but it somehow does not seem like a lot when you look at the incredible amount of stuff that is in there: towers, painted glasses, statues of biblical scenes and gargoyles, the list is endless. The city of Milan is synonymous with this structure.
Piazza Duomo
Should ideally be the starting point in the Milan tour. This immense open public space has the Cathedral, Galleria Vittorio and Church of Santa Maria delle Grazie (the one with Da Vinci’s The Last Supper) all in close proximity. The centre of the square has a large statue of Vittorio Emmanuel — the first king of united Italy (who also lends his name to the Galleria right by its side).
Galleria Vittorio Emmanuel
Resembles more a palace or an opera house, but is actually one of the world’s first shopping arcades created in 1877 by Giuseppe Mengoni. The walls and shop fronts have ornate stucco artwork and host the likes of Prada, Versace and other such brands that you can’t afford. Definitely not the place for bargains.
In the centre of the Galleria, the ground has mosaics portraying the coat of arms of the four capitals of the Kingdom of Italy — Turin, Florence, Rome and Milan.
Castello Sforzesco
A huge 15th-century castle close to the Cathedral. It was created in 1370 as a symbol of power and status. The front has a huge brick wall and tower, with interesting decorations. There are numerous small exhibits inside containing tidbits on the history of the castle and Milan.
Parco Sempione
A large public garden that sits behind the Sforzesco Castle, that has many walking trails, bike trails along with the odd statue and fountain. Throw in some street music performances, and it seems like all of Milan comes here to spend a leisurely evening.
At one end of the park is the Arch of Peace, built In 1807, under the Napoleonic rule, by Luigi Cagnola. Built in neoclassical style, it is decorated with a number of bas-reliefs and states depicting major events in the history of Italy and Europe.
Santa Maria del Suffragio
The church dates back to 1577, and the archbishop of Milan Carlo Borromeo who dedicated the parish to the cult of Santa Maria Nascente. The front facade has a depiction of Madonna enthroned with the Child.
San Siro
The location is a bit far off from the centre, but there was no way I was leaving Milan without visiting the San Siro. While the Milan clubs — Inter and AC Milan, have fallen on hard times of late, I can’t think of many stadiums that have witnessed more history than this one. This is where Kaka once wowed the world with his magical feet.
Navigli
Constructed originally in 1177, the canal has seen many changes over the years. Today it is one of the centres of Milanese Movida (nightlife). The waterfront and trails, with a variety of eateries, make it perfect for ending a day in this city.
Like most Italian cities, Milan is wonderful to walk around. While the city is much more spread out, it doesn’t seem like a big issue with a very efficient public transport network. There is also a huge student population, adding to the vibe.
Tip: If one has plans for Milan, it would be wise to book tickets to see The Last Supper painting at the Santa Maria delle Grazie well beforehand, because the queues go quite long. The lines are a hassle though, and if the time on your hand is limited, it might be worth reconsidering how much you want to devote to seeing just a painting.

Title: Milan Hiring Igli Tare is not Bad
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
1
Listen
Share
After about three months of searching, Milan finally have a new sporting director: Igli Tare. As the club has failed to qualify for European competitions next season and is more likely to finish ninth in the league this season than not, the heated atmosphere around the club hasn’t cooled off. Milan fans have had to experience one of the club’s worst seasons ever — at least relative to expectations — and they’ve been very well aware that poor management is what’s behind it, all the while Milan have actively been looking to make changes in that department. As such, people haven’t been thrilled that it has taken multiple months for this change to arrive, in fact now that it has arrived, the fans aren’t exactly convinced by the choice either. Well, my perspective on the sporting director recruitment process as well as its outcome differs, and in this article I’m going to attempt to sum up my thoughts under four relatively separate points.
Fair enough, Milan’s sporting director position has been vacant since December at the latest — that is if you choose to believe that a guy named Antonio D’Ottavio was previously the sporting director. Milan have had plenty of time to find their new sporting director, in fact first we were told that they would arrive at some point in March, then around Easter, and now the summer transfer market is about to open, and Milan still don’t *officially* have a sporting director. But, I do think it’s worth pointing out that this is not a shockingly late hire. I am writing this on 20 May, 2025, and on 29 May, 2024, the soon-to-be [I do recognize that this is a potential jinx] champions of Italy officialized the arrival of their current sporting director. That is to say, a club that finished 10th last season — subsequently missing out on European football and thereby also a lot of money — went on to hire a sporting director around the same time of the year as Milan are about to, and a year later said club is about to win the scudetto; they found success despite the arrival of their sporting director being left somewhat late. Still, one can be cynical towards the process behind this hire, and I understand that, in fact I have been fairly negative about Milan’s sporting director recruitment process for much of its span, but I do think there is a perfectly reasonable explanation for why it has taken so long.
Being more specific, some have made the point that it’s an indictment on Milan’s leadership that they spent numerous months working on bringing in a new sporting director — ultimately leaving things late — only to bring in someone who has been available all this time, and who probably isn’t the most exciting option. Again: I understand that. However, without knowing with certainty what has gone on behind the scenes, it appears quite clear how this recruitment process for Milan has developed, and I honestly don’t have a big problem with it. The media coverage of this process has been peculiar — it’s always difficult to know exactly which reports are true and which aren’t, and this process has been a unique example of false reports, from otherwise relatively reliable reporter, being confirmed as such. Some of the most reliable sources out there have barely been reporting on Milan’s sporting director recruitment process at all, other slightly less reliable sources have reported on it quite frequently. I would assume that the reality is that Milan have regularly been working on bringing in a new sporting director, and that the media has failed to get a grasp of the specific details. Names like Giovanni Sartori, Tony D’Amico, Giovanni Manna, Markus Krösche, Thiago Scuro, and even Cristiano Giuntoli have all been linked to Milan, and those links may not have been fabricated, even if the media has failed to accurately describe their connections to Milan. What all of these directors have in common is that they are under contract at their respective clubs. That is what this subheading is all about. The reason why Milan have taken so long to hire a sporting director, is likely that they have been attempting to hire guys who are currently under contract. Listen, I have strong opinions on this, but I have to say that that’s fair enough.
A counterpoint I have made to people who have been upset about Milan’s sporting director recruitment process is actually just a question: who would you hire if you were in charge? I feel like the only names I have seen people actively advocate for have been Giovanni Sartori, Tony D’Amico and Markus Krösche — the first name being by far the most popular one, if not the only popular one. Sure, I agree, I would probably try really hard to hire one of those guys if I were in charge too, in fact Tony D’Amico has been my favorite option for Milan for numerous months now. Let me be clear: I really, really, really, really want Milan to hire Tony D’Amico. If it were up to me, I would ask Atalanta how much it would take for them to let go of D’Amico, and then I would pay that price. Therefore, don’t take it lightly when I say that it is completely understandable that Tony D’Amico will not be the next sporting director of Milan. Why? Because hiring someone who is under contract is very difficult. If you can’t outright convince them to jump ship, you’re probably going to have to buy out their contract, and that might cost a pretty penny. In this case, we are talking about the premier sporting decision-maker of Milan’s regional- and competitive rivals, and while details about Atalanta’s different contracts are murky, D’Amico seems to have two years left on his. So, yeah, acquiring him is easier said than done. Should Milan simply have found a way? I absolutely think there is an argument to be made, sure — that’s usually how it works for clubs of Milan’s stature. As for my perspective, I don’t think there are many with as strong opinions on coaches and executives in football being undervalued as me — read this thread for example. And I am critical of Milan failing to hire D’Amico, but I don’t think it’s an outrage — it is quite clear that they tried, and it’s fully understandable why they failed. The same probably applies to all the other aforementioned directors.
About Giovanni Sartori, he extended his contract with Bologna shortly before it was widely reported that Milan’s search for a new sporting director was underway, so he, too, was going to be difficult for Milan to get… although not impossible. Here again I think criticism is fair; Milan could have done more. Yes, Sartori was essentially untouchable by the time Milan’s search for a new sporting director had seemingly begun, but this search could absolutely have begun earlier. In this case, Milan could have made quite a tempting offer to Sartori. By now, Sartori is a legendary figure in Italian football — perhaps the greatest sporting director of all time in my opinion — and there’s still gas left in the tank, but who knows how much? He turned 68 earlier this year, and up to this point in his career he is yet to manage one of the bigger clubs in Italy — in fact Bologna is the biggest one, which says a lot. By all means he doesn’t need to work at a bigger club for anyone’s sake, but doing so might be a very enticing challenge, and time is finite. It remains true that Sartori has only just won his first major trophy as an executive, and he has still never won a scudetto. If he were to take on such the challenge of taking over a bigger club, Milan would likely be the most compelling option, partly because there is a connection there. Sartori was born in Lodi, a city outside the metropolitan city of Milan, and he spent numerous years at Milan when he was younger. If Milan had been quicker to act, they might have been able to sway Sartori’s mind. Still, there are no guarantees, and I think Milan failing to hire neither D’Amico nor Sartori is a lot more disappointing than it is damning.
So, why did it take Milan so long to hire a sporting director? We can’t know for sure, but I think the reasonable assumption is that they were simply unable to acquire any of the top candidates, seeing as they were all under contract. Could they have done more? Again, I think the answer is yes, but Milan’s delicate financial situation makes the ultimate outcome even more understandable. Now, who else was available — aside from the directors that were under contract, that is? Well, there was Andrea Berta at one point, and Milan were supposedly interested, but beating Arsenal to that one was always going to be difficult. Some have brought up Paolo Maldini, who firstly has never worked as a sporting director, and who secondly was obviously never going to be considered by the same regime that pushed him out of the club less than two years ago. So, was Igli Tare the best option? In the sense that there’s a chance Milan might have been able to hire someone better if they just did more, no. That someone could have been a more enticing director option who was under contract, or an exciting name working in a non-sporting director role, but the former might outright not have been feasible, and the latter would have been risky. Among the clearly realistic options, I do think Igli Tare was, quite easily, the best option for Milan. On that note, I think it’s excessively cynical to describe this move as Milan settling for an unconvincing option because they failed to hire anyone else.
In his post-playing career, Igli Tare is only one thing up to this point: the (former) sporting director of Lazio. Tare spent about 15 years as an executive in the Italian capital, and there is a lot to like about the work he did over this span. In these years, Tare worked alongside Lazio owner and president Claudio Lotito, which is a challenge not only due to Lotito’s difficult character, but also due to the lack of money Lazio have been able to spend during his time there. Using transfer fees from Transfermarkt, I’m going to attempt to give you a rough idea of what Tare had to work with during his time at Lazio. Throughout Tare’s time at the club, Lazio made 13 signings with a total transfer fee of at least €10m — that’s less than one every year. Additionally, they only ever made two signings with a total transfer fee of at least €20m — Mauro Zárate for €23.2m, and Vedat Muriqi for €21m. Beyond that, Tare only spent €15m or more on a single player on three other occasions. On that note, let’s look at some of the players he signed while at Lazio:
The way I’d describe Igli Tare’s Lazio career is with this analogy: he was essentially like the general manager of an NFL franchise that was forced to almost exclusively use day three picks in the draft. With those picks inevitably came a lot of forgotten players — there were even some misses on higher picks here and there — but overall he was able to get an enormous amount of value compared to what he was working with; rotational guys in the seventh and sixth rounds, stopgap starters in the fifth round, 10-year starters in the fourth round, pro bowlers and all-pros in the third and second rounds. It’s true that Lazio experienced limited success during Tare’s tenure at the club, but context is important. In the aftermath of their golden era around Y2K, Lazio suffered significant financial issues and plummeted in the league table. By the time Tare took on an executive role at the club, Lazio were coming off of a 12th place finish in Serie A — this was the starting point for Tare, and, as established, he had extremely limited resources to take Lazio out of this position with. But so he did. By 2011, Lazio were back around the top of Italian football, finishing fifth in Serie A that year, and over the following 12 seasons they would only finish outside of the top seven three times, never falling below ninth.
The issues with Tare’s Lazio tenure were a few — none of which are all that significant in my opinion. Most importantly, I have found Lazio to be an incredibly frustrating club in recent years, and what the results above don’t show is how low Lazio’s ceiling has been since… well, since the late Sven-Göran Eriksson was at the club. Even with some exceptional coaches at their disposal, Lazio have rarely ever been much more than a Europa League caliber team. They qualified for the Champions League group stages twice during Tare’s time at the club, but ranked seventh in expected points in each of those seasons (via Understat). On two other occasions, Lazio came close to qualifying. In 2014–15, they technically qualified to the Champions League, but only to the play-off rounds, in which they were knocked out. In 2017–18, they suffered a legendary collapse on the final day to give the final Champions League spot to Inter — who they faced that day — but even that year they only ranked fifth in expected points, and a noticeable margin behind fourth at that. Of course, these are relatively superficial observations, but the point is that Lazio have consistently struggled to reach a competitive that really shouldn’t be unattainable to them… or should it? The way I’ve seen it, Lazio have largely failed to make the leap to a Champions League level due to there simply having been too many mediocre players in their squad — outstanding ones like Luis Alberto, Sergej Milinković-Savić and Ciro Immobile have only been able to pull so much weight. The sporting director is a natural scapegoat for this issue, and to circle back to the aforementioned issues with Tare’s time at Lazio, the fact that he really struggled to make many successful signings at all (even when given the chance to spend just a little bit more) in his final seasons at the club doesn’t bolster his case.
Well, to address both of those points one by one, I think Tare’s inability to build a more complete squad is perfectly understandable when you consider just how little he was working with. Another factor to consider here was that the players he brought in weren’t even cheap in the way some of Inter’s signings have been under the leadership of Giuseppe Marotta in recent years. In Marotta’s case, his Inter have signed numerous aging players of at least a relatively high profile — either for free or for a very low transfer fee. Whereas that kind of low-cost signing usually comes with relatively high wages, though, Tare’s focus on players of incredibly low profile has meant that his players have been paid significantly less. In fact, that’s telling it in the wrong order; Tare’s budget has rather been so tight — both in terms of transfer fees and wages — that he has been (more or less) forced into signing these unproven, low-profile players. There is no other way to describe it: Igli Tare squeezed water out of a stone during his time at Lazio.
Now, again, Tare did have a few whiffs here and there — particularly in later seasons, and partly when he was allowed to spend a bit more — but the context behind Tare’s final years at Lazio bring us to the third and final reasonable reservation against Tare. There have been many instances in which Tare has been shown to have a stern, fiery personality, but is this anything to be too concerned about? Well, I don’t want this discussion to become too convoluted, but I think we should go there. To be concise, Milan’s current sporting regime has frequently been described as consisting of people who are out of their depth, as well as lacking leadership and internal harmony. Adding a potentially problematic personality to that equation may seem like a recipe for disaster, but Tare’s time at Lazio was by no means plagued by scandals, and more importantly he spent 15 years working alongside Claudio Lotito; he survived 15 years of Claudio Lotito, so he should be able to survive Milan’s current management. Tare didn’t survive 16 years alongside Lotito, though, and that’s where his problematic final years at Lazio tie into this issue. Part of the problem with these final years is that Tare just made indefensible mistakes — making players like Manuel Lazzari and Vedat Muriqi some of his most expensive signings ever, for instance. Still, even in those seasons he had limited resources to work with, and especially in his last two seasons at the club, a problematic relationship with then-Lazio coach Maurizio Sarri as well as the arrival of current Lazio sporting director Angelo Fabiani didn’t help. More importantly, however, I think the main reason why Lazio consistently failed to break into Serie A’s top four is that they were unwilling to sell. Sergej Milinković-Savić, Luis Alberto and Ciro Immobile is the holy trinity of Tare signings at Lazio — they were brought in for a total fee lower than €30m (via Transfermarkt), but went on to become among the best in the world in their respective roles. It’s an unromantic way of looking at things, but I also think it’s a pragmatic one. In the end, Lazio only made a total of €52.3m from the sales of these players, and the truth is that they could have made at least three times more, and they would have been better off. The financial influx that could have come with these monumentally successful signings would have given Lazio the opportunity to move away from their usual €5m signings and really bolster their squad. Supposedly, it was precisely Lotito who was more opposed to this idea, so Tare could ultimately only do so much.
I’m joking. I really am. Or am I? Well, you know what really, really matters? I guess it depends on the club, but for any club that isn’t extremely rich, a competent sporting regime/front office really matters. It matters a ton — like, perhaps more than anything else. That does not equate to a sporting director being all that important, though. A crucial point in regards to this move is that sporting director is ultimately only a job title — it does not have any intrinsic meaning. Much has been made of Milan’s sporting director recruitment process… or, well, for the most part people have just been complaining about the fact that Milan haven’t hired on (until now, of course). In any case, the implication has been that Milan’s lack of a sporting director has been a problem because the summer is rapidly approaching, and sporting directors are important. That’s not necessarily true, though. Milan’s previous sporting director was almost completely anonymous, and that may not have been a reflection of his role at the club — or lack thereof — but, well, it probably was. Almost certainly, Antonio D’Ottavio wasn’t a sporting director in the way sporting directors are generally perceived — that is, a-/the leading figure of the sporting department of the men’s first team, as well as potentially even overseer of the women’s team, the youth sector, and the finances of the club. Is that the role Igli Tare well get, though? Well, that’s the reason why I think people are making too big of a deal of this hire as well as Milan’s preceding recruitment process — we just don’t know what this means for the club. What I do know is that Igli Tare is very talented, and I seriously, seriously doubt that this move will backfire on account of Tare’s lack of competence. Still, this move might not move the needle for Milan, but my point is that in that case I don’t think hiring Tare will have been the issue. Instead, it will have been something else related to the current sporting regime. So, what is the issue with the current sporting regime; what is the reason for Milan’s terrible decision-making over the past two years? I’ve had many different theories, and, well, if I’m going to be less boring and not just conclude this article with “we’ll see if this ends up being good or not”, I do think that CEO Giorgio Furlani is one of the main culprits. He’s a finance guy who, by many accounts, seems to have a prevalent role in even the sporting decisions the club makes. In fact, when there have been reports of a lack of harmony within the management of the club, he has almost always been involved — at least since he took on his current role. Techncial director Geoffrey Moncada, on the other hand, had an excellent track record as a scout prior to his promotion, and I really struggle to believe that he’s the one making bad sporting decisions and electing to bring in players like Kyle Walker and João Félix.
What I want as a fan of Milan, is a revamp of their managerial structure; a transition towards a sporting regime/front office consisting of talented people in clear roles, and with a shared vision for the club. What exactly has to be done to achieve that I do not know. Maybe this appointment does the trick, or at least helps. Going back to Furlani, I do specifically suspect that he has simply been given too much power and influence within the club due to a lack of prevalent sporting figures aside from Moncada… Moncada who is still yet to turn 40, and who is working as a director for the first time in his career. As for Moncada, I think the narrative that he has failed because being a scout is different from being a director is incredibly lazy. Perhaps it’s true in a sense — the results are the results — but what I don’t buy is the notion that Moncada just isn’t competent enough to be a director. Again, does going from a chief scout to a technical director make you suddenly ditch your Milos Kerkez’s for your Emerson Royal’s and Kyle Walker’s? Well, in practice maybe yes, but in that case we are once more speaking about a structural issue more so than a widespread personnel issue; we are speaking about Moncada’s lack of influence and autonomy more so than his lack of competence. How do you address that? Well, depending on Tare’s role, I think he could help. By adding Tare, you add another prominent sporting-/technical figure to the picture, and perhaps that decreases the influence of Furlani in the club’s sporting process. Additionally, I don’t think it’s completely untrue that being a director is more difficult than being a scout. It’s not as though Moncada doesn’t understand that recruitment is not just about evaluating a player’s strengths and weaknesses, but also about evaluating how they could fit at your club. How this is done, on the other hand, is something that I do think Tare simply has a better grasp of. Another possibly decisive factor is Tare’s extensive network of agents, as well as his experience in dealing with these people. I don’t think it’s unlikely that Moncada’s relative weakness in this department has led to so-called agent-scouting perpetrated by Furlani at Milan over these past two years — that is, agent connections having a greater influence on recruitment than player assessment. Now, Tare’s work at Lazio is said to have been very independent, and it has even been claimed by some that he hasn’t been all that into working with scouts and/or utilizing data analysis for his recruitment, but these claims have indirectly been contradicted by recent reports that Tare has an excellent relationship with Geoffrey Moncada. In fact, these reports also claim that Tare really isn’t being brought in to take on a more superficial role, but rather one that is more in line with the traditional interpretation of the sporting director. The implication is that we will no longer be talking about the duo of Moncada and Furlani, but rather of the duo of Moncada and Tare — two sporting minds who I think compliment each other a lot better on paper. Both are exceptionally gifted at discovering talent — especially on restricted budgets — but the person who is being brought in is a lot more savvy when it comes to the process of actually signing players and constructing a successful team. With what we’ve seen over the past two years, don’t be surprised if shit hits the fan very quick, but I do legitimately think there is reason to be optimistic about this.

Boo and I managed to drag ourselves out of bed early-ish this morning for our date with Leonardo. Leonardo and I have had a travel thing going on for a couple of decades now, so I think people may be starting to talk. The last two times I was in France, there were major Leonardo exhibits at the Louvre.
This time, I thought that Leonardo and I were not going to be able to hook up in Milan. Usually, you have to buy tickets to see The Last Supper months in advance, and as you may know, I threw this whole trip together about a week before we left. But thanks to the singing tour guide from yesterday, I heard that there were some last minute openings for this morning, and I was able to snag a couple of tickets. And best of all, I didn’t even have to hear her sing about it!

Title: My Trip To Milan Was Almost Ruined
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in

Adventures and misadventures as we travel the world. Are you a traveller looking for a home for your stories? Your true travel stories are welcome. Ask to become a writer.

Featured
--
6
Listen
Share
Working as a fashion forecaster, I decided a trip to Milan would give me some inspiration for my clients.
I’m rather bohemian when it comes to my own style of clothing. More Janis Joplin crossed with Jimi Hendrix and a touch of Keith Richards than Audrey Hepburn.
However, I had carefully curated a capsule wardrobe with an assortment of elegant, high-quality clothes with designer labels for times like these.
I was looking forward to elevating my look for a few days. My dreadlocks would be hidden under a selection of colourful turbans, and I chose my favourite Givenchy jacket to wear for the journey.
I wanted to create the right impression as soon as I entered the hotel.
I couldn’t decide which handbag to accompany my outfits and eventually settled for a Vivienne Westwood because her bags are like the Tardis.
I felt rather special for a change as I admired each outfit in the bedroom mirror before packing it into my suitcase.
I was all set to go,
classy shoes, check.
An assortment of elegant suits and dresses, check.
Handbags, jackets, and accessories check.
Fashion capital of the world, here I come..
The day before my flight, I had a thorough clean around the house, dusting and mopping all the floors. It’s always nice to walk back into a tidy home after a trip away. It gives you that glad to be home feeling.
Everything was going well until I dropped a heavy glass paperweight on my foot.
The paperweight is antique and incredibly heavy with sharp edges. Immediately, I heard my toe pop.
I knew in an instant that the toe was broken as I tried to stop the blood flow and keep it elevated.
A few hours later, I tried a pair of shoes on, but it was useless.
My foot was swelling, and I was due at the airport in the early hours of the morning.
I had to choose, either cancel the vacation or strap my toe up and soldier on.
I decided on the latter because I had looked forward to visiting Milan for months.
It was far too painful to bandage my toe, so I decided to let the air get to it and hope for the best.
I tried on various shoes, trainers, and mules, but I just couldn’t cope with anything touching my toe.
So, out of the suitcase came the flattering heels and in went a pair of old fluffy, pink slippers.
The only item of footwear that would go anywhere near my injured foot apart from a battered pair of flip flops for nipping outside to the dustbin.
The moment of departure arrived, and I tried to manage the tedious journey of buses, trains, and planes wearing flip flops.
It was very painful. My toe was throbbing and in-between my toes bled where they were rubbing the skin.
Eventually, I arrived in Milan.
It was raining heavily, and as soon as I had stepped off the coach, I stood in a huge puddle.
Tired and sore with a heavy suitcase, I managed to limp into my hotel, looking like someone out of Fraggle Rock.
I’d forgotten about piling my long red locks into a pretty turban and felt like a hot mess.
This was not the impression I had been hoping to make.
I tried convincing myself that my toe would feel better tomorrow, and I would not be visiting The Last Supper in wet fluffy pink slippers.
I went to sleep with my gigantic toe poking out of the quilt like a Belisha beacon and my soggy slippers drying on the heater.
The following morning, I got up early to take a tram, but my foot was now a nice shade of black and blue, I applied some cream to help with the bruising and got myself dressed.
I was kitted out from head to toe in a smart plaid outfit made from high-quality fabric. I paired this with a designer handbag and worn, misshapen pink fluffy slippers, which the dogs lay on when they were pining for me.
I told myself “no one will care.”
I hobbled out of the hotel, barely able to walk on one foot and made my way to the tram stop.
Everyone was looking at me, and I was very wrong. They certainly did care.
Apparently, footwear is the most important part of putting together an outfit for the Italians, and I was getting some very peculiar looks.
I felt very self-conscious as I noticed people’s eye’s automatically drawn to my feet, accompanied by a mixture of distasteful looks and sniggers.
I must have looked a sight trying to keep up with my tour guide.
I soon forgot my predicament when I saw The Last Supper.
The fresco took me by surprise, and I was enchanted at how it had stood the test of time. I sat for a while, taking in the scene alone with my thoughts..
The point of my trip was to gain inspiration for putting together a budget version of the latest trends for my clients. The next stop was the designer boutiques for a few photo opportunities and a spot of people watching.
Walking along the Via Montenapoleone, I felt slightly nauseous. The slippers were now stretched out of shape, and I was struggling to keep them on.
The pain was almost unbearable, and by this point, my mood was rather low.
I was beginning to resent people who judge others so harshly based on their appearance.
I wondered why I hadn’t just cancelled the trip instead of hoping for a miraculous recovery. I was fed up with all the sniggers off passers-by, and I was aware of how ridiculous I looked.
I decided to abandon the idea of wandering around plush designer boutiques for the moment and treat myself to a couple of cocktails overlooking the Duomo.
I was grateful for an Aperol Spritz or two and the opportunity to sit for a while admiring the wonderful view.
The Duomo is breathtakingly beautiful.
I thought to myself what a fantastic experience it would be to go to the top of it and see the views over Milan.
I finished my drink and limped across the busy square. A tour guide told me there was an elevator to take tourists up to the top of the Duomo.
I was very excited, I queued for the elevator and couldn’t wait to experience the amazing skyline of Milan in the sunshine.
As soon as I reached the top, I felt slightly wobbly, but I was glad that I had taken the decision to do it. The views from different parts of the rooftop were incredible.
I decided to head back down and have a bite to eat before attempting to walk along the busy streets,observing the beautiful people of Milan in their full glory once again.
I asked where the elevator was and was told there wasn’t one for going back down. I gulped and began the arduous walk down the narrow, twisting steps.
It seemed to take ages, I peered out of each little window to see how far I’d got but never seemed to be getting any further near ground level.
Eventually, I was back in the square and happily tucking into a delicious pasta dish with the finest coffee I’d ever tasted.
After lunch and a rest, I set off once more, dragging my body along the streets amongst the wealthy shoppers carrying their purchases in fancy bags.
The window displays were very eye-catching, but the pavements needed a bit of attention. I was also slightly surprised by the amount of graffiti everywhere.
People of all ages graced the streets, showcasing their most outrageous and most decadent styles.
It was a sight to behold.
I observed a few ideas that I might be able to recreate for my clients. I took note of what the latest fashion trends are and how to pair outfits together with various accessories and jewellery to give them a certain ‘je ne sais quoi’.
I would be able to source a selection of ethical, conscious garments from local thrift shops to put together the same look for a fraction of the price.
I took a few snapshots of the area for my son, who is at an age where labels on clothing matter and then decided to head back to my hotel.
The following days were pleasant, and gradually, my painful toe began to feel slightly better.
I particularly loved visiting the spectacular churches.
I enjoyed the evenings, sipping coffee and listening to the musicians playing in the square whilst admiring the Duomo. It looked very atmospheric when the lights came on.
I peered down at my slippers as if to thank them for their loyalty and for helping me to negotiate the cobbled streets without tripping over.
How I had looked forward to being part of the in crowd in my tailored suits and glamorous footwear. I smiled at the realisation that perhaps this had all been a lesson.
I wasn’t being authentic in the expensive, fashionable capsule wardrobe I’d carefully put together. I’m an old hippie at heart.
I love bangles, beads, and flowing maxi dresses. The feeling of freedom and individuality, not afraid to be different from the crowd.
I don’t fit in with the people who only wear the latest trends.
I finished my coffee and made my way back to the courtyard of my hotel.
One last Aperol Spritz for the road and then back home to my two dogs tomorrow.
They can keep my pink fluffy slippers, I don’t think I’ll be wearing them again…

Title: Milan Ehrhardt on the Future of AI & Human-Centered Computing
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Computers have always worked the same way. You give a command, they execute. But what if technology didn’t need commands? What if AI simply knew what you wanted, when you needed it? That shift isn’t just coming, it’s already happening.
Right now, interacting with technology means constantly switching between apps, searching for files, and manually organising everything. We’ve accepted this as normal, but it doesn’t have to be.
Milan Ehrhardt is interested in where computing is going next. The next generation of AI isn’t just about making computers faster or smarter, it’s about making them think more like humans. Instead of waiting for inputs, AI is starting to anticipate needs, recognise intent, and assist before you even ask.
It’s not just about efficiency. It’s about rethinking what a computer actually is.
Right now, most interactions with technology are transactional: Want to book a flight? Open five tabs, compare prices, and manually enter your info. Need to find a file? Dig through folders or search for the exact name.
We’ve gotten so used to doing things this way that we don’t question it. But Milan Ehrhardt believes AI-driven computing is on the verge of something bigger, something that understands what you need before you even ask.
The next wave of AI isn’t about adding more features, it’s about making technology feel invisible by removing friction.
Instead of forcing people to adapt to technology, the best AI will adapt to the way people actually think and work.
Today’s computing experience is fragmented. Everything requires jumping between apps. One for calendars, another for messaging, another for project management etc. The entire experience is built around constantly switching between tools instead of just getting things done.
But Milan Ehrhardt sees a different future. Instead of optimising for more features, the best AI will focus on removing friction entirely.
No more jumping between a dozen apps.No more manually searching, organising, or coordinating.No more rigid, one-size-fits-all software.
The best AI won’t just be another tool, it’ll be a true extension of how people think and operate.
Would you rather have one AI system that does everything or a collection of specialised tools?
The internet today is designed for mass adoption. Big tech companies build platforms for billions of users, creating generic experiences that work for everyone, but aren’t perfect for anyone.
The next generation of AI computing flips that model. Instead of optimising for scale, the real breakthroughs will be in personalisation, where technology finally works the way people do.
Instead of being built for the masses, the next generation of computing will be built for the individual.
AI-powered communication, automation, and workflow optimisation aren’t just trends, they’re redefining how people work, connect, and create.
In the next few years, Milan Ehrhardt expects companies building this kind of technology to completely change the way people interact with computers. Not by adding more features, but by removing the barriers that make computers frustrating to use in the first place.
That shift is happening fast. The question isn’t if AI will transform everyday interactions, it’s who will build the version that people actually want to use?

Title: Milan
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
David
Our fleeting eye contact overwhelms me as you dance topless before me. I sit alone, front row center, while other customers slouch distracted in dark corners.
Does staring into your eyes make you uncomfortable? Would you prefer I watch your breasts? The diamond in your navel? The curve of your back? I’d understand — it’s less intimate than holding your gaze.
Monday night, nearly closing. Three men nurse drinks without looking up from their phones. You move under harsh lights, but when our eyes meet, your performance transforms. Becomes intentional.
I came here running from Sarah’s absence — six weeks of silence echoing through my apartment. Thought paying for attention might ease the ache. Instead, watching you navigate between performance and truth, I’ve found something deeper.
You step closer, near enough that I catch your scent beneath the club’s stale air. Your eyes ask questions I can’t answer, searching my face like you’re trying to solve a puzzle. There’s vulnerability in how you tilt your head, curiosity in your expression.
You gesture toward the bar with raised eyebrows — an invitation that feels more like a lifeline than transaction. Two isolated souls finding unexpected recognition.
Milan
This one’s different. Sits front row but watches my face, not my body. Makes me nervous in ways I’d forgotten possible.
Most men here want fantasy — the girlfriend experience without emotional cost. They stare at my breasts, my ass, the diamond piercing my navel. Safe objectification that keeps distance between who I am and what I do.
But he meets my eyes. Holds them. Makes this feel less like performance, more like… what? Connection? Dangerous thinking for a Tuesday shift.
His loneliness radiates like heat. Recent breakup, probably — I recognize the hollow look. Usually I’d exploit that, milk sympathy for extra tips. But something stops me. Maybe how his stare lacks hunger, contains only recognition.
I move closer, testing boundaries. He doesn’t leer or make crude gestures. Just watches with an intensity that should feel invasive but doesn’t. Like he sees through the costume, the makeup, straight to whoever I was before this.
When I gesture toward the bar, he nods immediately. Not calculating cost or anticipating service — just accepting invitation.
I finish my set mechanically, mind elsewhere. Been dancing three years, perfected the art of emotional distance. But this stranger’s gaze has cracked something open. Made me remember what it felt like to be seen as human rather than commodity.
Two more songs, then I’ll discover if this moment means what it feels like — or if I’m just another lonely person mistaking transaction for connection

Title: BRUTALIST MILAN VOL.1
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
Milan is a city of contrasts, and brutalism embodies this duality perfectly: loved and hated, criticised and misunderstood, yet to me, fascinating in its rawness.
Its power lies in the material, in the boldness of its forms, in the honesty of exposed concrete that isn’t afraid to reveal itself for what it is.
My journey begins with Torre Velasca, an icon rising against the gray sky. I lift my camera and press the shutter. My focus lands on the barricades obstructing the view, while the architecture in the background dissolves into a blur. A technical mistake, perhaps, but also a sign. This accidental shot becomes the cover of my journey, a starting point that encapsulates the essence of my project: the dialogue between brutalism and time, between permanence and change.
I move towards Sant’Ambrogio quarter, where the geometric lines of the Collegio di Milano stand sharp against the still air. Its edges carve into the sky, while the soft February light glides over the concrete, emphasizing its texture. Shadows stretch across the rough surfaces, deepening their presence. The atmosphere is suspended, the silence charged with meaning.
I continue to the Church of San Giovanni Bono, where spirituality merges with the brutality of raw concrete. The solid mass envelops the space with its solemn presence. I feel small before its towering weight, yet somehow balanced by the harmony of its forms. Every detail speaks of resilience, of a delicate equilibrium between heaviness and lightness.
Going back, I unexpectedly encounter a municipal building, a relic of a past era. The cracked concrete whispers tales of abandonment, of a quiet struggle against time. Though worn and weathered, its structure holds a stubborn dignity. I press the shutter as the sun begins to set, capturing the shadows creeping into its fissures. My film roll is nearly finished.
Finally, my gaze is drawn to TheTris — what I like to call “New Brutalism” (I know, architecture purists, it’s not the correct description). Here, glass and concrete intertwine, linearity meets monumentality, and the past blends with the future. It is the perfect closing chapter, a final destination that hints at a new perspective.
One last shot. The film roll is done.
Shooting on film is my way of giving these structures back their substance. The grain of the film merges with the roughness of the concrete, each imperfection becoming part of the narrative. Through every frame, brutalism turns into a story — an ongoing dialogue between time and space, between what is built and what is lived. An architecture that is eternal, precisely because it can decay, endure, and transform without ever truly disappearing.

Title: The Struggle of Memory against Forgetting: Why Milan Kundera Matters
Content:
Sign up
Sign in
Sign up
Sign in
--
Listen
Share
i.
Kundera almost killed me, still in my creative cradle, a writer needing nourishment.
He arrived in my life too early. As a reader, it wasn’t soon enough, as what relatively inexperienced but enthusiastic amateur — fresh from the front lines of grad school and adjusting to a world without texts to deconstruct — won’t benefit from that kind of sophisticated guidance, at any age? Still, as an aspiring writer, Kundera’s work had the odd effect of inspiring me, only too much. You read accumulated wisdom of this caliber and feel desperate, like a creature trudging through the heat in search of an oasis. Finally, you happen across a patch of water, lapping up every drop, half insane with relief and oblivious to the crocodiles lurking hungrily in the shallows.
Reading Kundera at any age, particularly as an aspiring writer with a future filed under “TBD,” you don’t just want to write like him, you want to be him. On some level you understand: in order to write like that you have to have lived like that. Eventually — and the sooner the better — you recognize it’s an impossibility and, choices narrowed to one, you lick your wounds and get on with the unbearable lightness of being yourself.
ii.
Context, of course, is everything.
I read Kundera in a pre-Internet world, and I wonder how disconsonant to our 21st Century insanity his work will be, going forward. Kundera, a man out of time is, in some ways, more easily connected — spiritually, aesthetically — to his heroes from centuries past than any of his peers, artistic or otherwise, today. He was an old soul, certainly, but a creative one; he undoubtedly ruffled the feathers of ancient gods, watching him with envy and pity as he encroached on the sublime, aloof from the mere mortals he walked amongst, no safe home here or in heaven.
His chief subject, he told the Paris Review, was not politics or social criticism but the “complexity of human existence in the modern world.”
It’s not coincidental that his best-loved books were written during years when intellectuals pondered if we’d lived through the end of history. No ivory tower elitist, he had dirt under his fingernails (at least figuratively) and knew what gunpowder smelled like; he also was talented and famous enough to remove himself (as the best artists aspire to do; the middling poseurs content with making as much money as possible) from the numbing grind, having the luxury to obsess about matters of the heart and mind. One imagines he never bothered to buy a computer or send an email.
If men of his time (and place) had seen the horrors of war and oppression up close, they also enjoyed the creative fruits of ennui. Being bored, they obsessed about the one thing any man, freed from worrying about food or work, focuses on: women. His novels will be uneasy reads for future generations, their female characters often anything but fully formed — at least in ways where their primary purpose is to serve or be adored (Kundera was not above cliché, speaking of women as muses and ostensibly intending it as a compliment).
One thing he could not be accused of, to his credit, is denial. As imperious and intolerant of convention as he could be, he knew what he was, and was refreshingly candid about his limitations. “Every one of my novels could be entitled The Unbearable Lightness of Being or The Joke or Laughable Loves,” he said. “They reflect the small number of themes that obsess me, define me and, unfortunately, restrict me. Beyond these themes, I have nothing else to say or to write.”
The best novelists, of course, combine the dispassionate insight of a historian, the elan of an iconoclast, and the empathy of a social worker. They are, as Shelley declared, our world’s unacknowledged legislators. Except they are, of course, acknowledged, and their work endures long past the expiration dates of celebrities, politicians, and professors. A more measured and succinct assessment, courtesy of another Great White Male from the old school, John Updike, who wrote “Kundera makes the life histories of most American writers look as stolid as the progress of a tomato plant, and it is small wonder that Kundera is able to merge personal and political significances with the ease of a Camus.”
iii.
In Testaments Betrayed Kundera explains his vision of the novelist’s acumen, which is “a considered, stubborn, furious nonidentification, conceived not as evasion or passivity but as resistance, defiance, rebellion.”
That’s about the best mission statement for any writer I’ve ever come across, and is the closest thing to personal mantra, or creed, that has consoled and inspired me, almost thirty years after I first read it. I came to appreciate Kundera as an ideal distillation of two other writers who did their best work last century, Martin Amis and Christopher Hitchens. In his art, which audaciously combined fiction, criticism, and philosophical ruminations, he seemed to possess Amis’s impeccable style and Hitchens’s indefatigable erudition, the wary traveler who’d seen and read everything, had an opinion about all of it, and steadfastly refused identification with any cause or tribe.
In The Book of Laughter and Forgetting, Kundera writes: The struggle of man against power is the struggle of memory against forgetting.
Perhaps, in an unwelcome, if sadly familiar and even predictable epoch wherein book banning on a mass scale has become a political barometer, and the cultural marketplace of ideas is intentionally flooded with noise, where info-overload is a default setting, where we’re always in danger of forgetting, we can return to Kundera. Maybe his work will find relevance — and resonance — in ways it wasn’t even a decade ago. It’s possible he will invariably be considered alongside Orwell and Kafka, who also depicted our seemingly unappeasable appetite for destruction. Kundera will remind us why we must laugh at the cynical, if deeply absurd agitators who divide us and thrive when we tend to forget.
--
